title: 1. Louie’s Role & Early 1982 Construction at Simpson Creek
chapter: 1. Louie’s Role & Early 1982 Construction at Simpson Creek
summary: The reel opens with a posed shot of Louie Ellis as 'Film Director & Producer,' then cuts to July 4, 1982 on-site interviews at the raw Meadowbrook/Pete Dye site. James D. LaRosa and others thank Louie for filming 'for our own historical reasons' and joke about 'no charge.' The camera then documents a burned railroad/road bridge on the lower end of No. 9 fairway, heavy equipment cleaning decades of strip‑mine silt from Simpson Creek, and bulldozers shaping the future clubhouse area, first tee, and 18th green. Narration explains plans to dam the creek, deepen it for boating and fishing, and rough‑grade all 18 fairways by late 1982 for a 1984 opening.

title: James D. thanks Louie for filming 'for our own historical reasons'
summary: On July 4, 1982, standing on a raw construction site near Simpson Creek, James D. LaRosa looks into Louie’s camera and thanks him for taking pictures of 'our operation,' saying they’ll always appreciate having them for historical reasons and noting that Louie has been a friend for years.

title: 2. Underground Mine, Coal Heritage & Routing of Holes 6–7
chapter: 2. Underground Mine, Coal Heritage & Routing of Holes 6–7
summary: The film moves into the coal‑mine heritage of the property. We see the LaRosa Fuel Co. portals and the rotary car dump (tipple) that once rotated coal cars to empty them. James D. and Jimmy explain that golf carts will travel through a deep mine between the 6th green and 7th tee, making the mine an integral part of the routing. Pete Dye, Max Robinson, and the LaRosas walk the 6th fairway, discuss blocking off an old road, and debate whether golfers should be forced through the mine. Pete praises the property as 'the most dramatic' he’s seen and jokes about West Virginians and hillbillies. They also discuss coal cinder bunkers, stone walls, and how the course will echo Scottish coal‑yard features like St Andrews’ road hole.

title: Frank Etterie predicts national recognition for the course
summary: Standing on the 13th tee, longtime friend and Winged Foot member Frank Etterie gives a detailed, thoughtful critique, calling the development unique, praising Pete Dye’s design and Jim LaRosa’s 'no expense spared' approach, and predicting that the course will become one of the best‑known in the United States.

title: Frank Etterie compares the course to Pine Valley and Winged Foot
summary: Frank describes the course as a shot‑maker’s layout where bad shots are penalized by trees and meadows rather than adjacent fairways. He notes that while some compare it to Pine Valley, he prefers this hilly, hardwood‑lined style, similar to the course he grew up on, and says everything is being done 'in a first‑class way.'

title: 3. 1983–1985: Creek Cleaning, Bridge Building & Entrance Road
chapter: 3. 1983–1985: Creek Cleaning, Bridge Building & Entrance Road
summary: By 1983–85, the footage shows more organized earthmoving: end loaders and scrapers cleaning Simpson Creek, D9 and D6 dozers pushing silt to build up fairways and future sod farms, and workers installing large drain pipes under fairways. James D. narrates in detail how sediment, coal fines, and trash are removed, how abutments are jackhammered and blasted, and how a salvaged steel bridge from Thornton, WV is repurposed over Simpson Creek for both play and maintenance. We see the entrance road near Jimmy Joe’s house, sulfur water from an old Consol mine, and the first glimpses of shaped fairways (No. 2, No. 18 landing area) with temporary play and fertilizer spreading. Interviews with workers and friends (e.g., Raymondo Frazzilio) praise specific holes and the overall potential of the course.

title: 4. Pete Dye on Strategy, Self‑Contained Design & Greatness
chapter: 4. Pete Dye on Strategy, Self‑Contained Design & Greatness
summary: On a partially grassed front nine, Pete Dye is finally captured on tape. Standing with James D. and Jimmy, he calls himself 'Mr. LaRosa’s assistant' and describes the property as unequaled: a self‑contained golf course with no houses, dramatic hillsides, and distinctive vistas on every hole. He explains what makes great courses—natural backdrops, strategic variety, and finished details—and compares the coal‑mine and rock features here to Scottish precedents (sleepers, coal yards at St Andrews). He predicts that if they finish as planned, this will be a truly great golf course. The LaRosas and Max discuss final grading tweaks, ladies’ tees, and how little remains to fix on the front nine.

title: Pete Dye calls the property 'the most dramatic' he’s seen
summary: On a partially grassed front nine, Pete Dye, flanked by James D. and Jimmy, says he’s never seen anything more dramatic than this piece of property and that if this isn’t a great golf course, he doesn’t know what is. He emphasizes the self‑contained nature of the course and the combination of strategy and natural vistas.

title: Pete Dye on coal, Scotland, and sleepers
summary: In a conversation near the coal‑mine hole, Pete explains that using railroad ties ('sleepers') and coal features is nothing new—Scots did it a hundred years ago to stop erosion and that St Andrews had a coal yard at the 17th road hole. He says Jim is 'just restoring' things done in the old country, tying the course’s coal heritage to golf history.

title: 5. 1985–1986: Seeding, Mounding & Outside Voices
chapter: 5. 1985–1986: Seeding, Mounding & Outside Voices
summary: Mid‑80s footage shows the course taking shape: topsoil, lime, phosphate, and seed being applied around the 17th green; rye overseeding for erosion control; and permanent bluegrass/bentgrass interfaces explained by a superintendent. Jimmy notes they’re as far along as ever and hope to open in about a year. On No. 12, James D. and operator Steve Helmig build a mound that will create a blind shot if you play too safe off the tee. We see the Mazzee brothers building bridge abutments, and more drainage and stonework. Longtime friend Frank Etterie (from New Rochelle/Winged Foot) gives a detailed, glowing critique of the course, comparing it favorably to Pine Valley and Scottish classics, and praising Jim LaRosa’s determination to create a first‑class, shot‑maker’s course in a coal‑mining region.

title: 6. Lakes, Fountains, Triploid Carp & Finished Water Features
chapter: 6. Lakes, Fountains, Triploid Carp & Finished Water Features
summary: Attention shifts to the creation and refinement of the course’s lakes. We see the No. 1 lake with a floating fountain unit; James D. explains its dual purpose: aeration for fish life and algae control. Special triploid carp from Arkansas (via Pittsburgh) are acclimated and released into the lake under the supervision of Gary Davis and Bob Andrew, with Louie filming up close. Later, James D. stands by the lake as the two Otterbine fountains are turned on for the first time, describing their 15–18 foot 'rocket' spray and planned colored lights for nighttime views from the future clubhouse. Scenic shots show the completed spillway, rock cascades, and misty lakes with ducks and geese, contrasting sharply with earlier muddy creek footage.

title: First fountains and triploid carp in No. 1 lake
summary: At the No. 1 lake, James D. explains the purpose of the floating fountains and special triploid carp, then we see the first fountain turned on, shooting a 'rocket' spray into the air. The group listens to the sound of the water and jokes about whether the wall will wash away, while James D. thanks engineer George Duffer for assuring them it would work.

title: 7. Family, Pets & Louie’s Running 'No Charge' Gag
chapter: 7. Family, Pets & Louie’s Running 'No Charge' Gag
summary: Interspersed with construction are intimate family and social moments: Louie films dogs and cats around a house and fenced yard; an older man in a tan coat (likely James D.) holds and introduces multiple cats ('Tiger,' 'Bunker,' 'Coldust,' 'Silky'), joking that this is 'the other side of Jim LaRosa’s life.' Louie introduces his nephew Anthony Ellis as his 'backup man' and gives his phone number on camera. In another scene, Louie theatrically hands James D. and friends a single dollar bill, insisting on proving on TV that he 'paid to take the movies.' Group shots on the old tracks and at the raspberry patch show the extended LaRosa/Ellis circle laughing, hugging, and acknowledging that Louie has been filming 'no charge' since 1978.

title: 8. Industrial Heritage: Tipple, Rotary Car Dump & LaRosa Fuel Portals
chapter: 8. Industrial Heritage: Tipple, Rotary Car Dump & LaRosa Fuel Portals
summary: The film documents the industrial structures that will become part of the course’s identity. We see the old rotary car dump (tipple) where coal cars were rotated and emptied, and the LaRosa Fuel Co. No. 6 and No. 7 portals. James D. explains how cars came from the hill, were dumped, and coal loaded into trucks. The group (LaRosas, friends, and Louie) stands at the portals, connecting the site to their immigrant and mining heritage. They explain that the exhibition mine and tipple will be preserved as tourist‑like attractions and integrated into holes (e.g., the coal‑mine portal visible behind the 6th green). This industrial past is explicitly linked to Scottish coal‑yard precedents and to the course’s unique character.

title: 9. Clay Models & Master Plans: Visualizing Holes 8 & the Clubhouse Core
chapter: 9. Clay Models & Master Plans: Visualizing Holes 8 & the Clubhouse Core
summary: A hand‑built clay model on the grass is used to explain a dramatic redesign of the 8th hole: a high wall around the green, a 'Grand Canyon effect' from the putting surface, and a cavernous bunker bottom filled with coal cinders. James D. notes that Pete Dye said most great holes lack the 'frame' this wall will provide. Later, indoors, a professional scale model and a large colored master plan are shown. A presenter (likely James D. or an architect) points out the clubhouse, 18th green, 1st tee, 9th green, 10th tee, practice tee, putting green, chalet/temporary office, entrance garden with rock flower bed and fountain, two rock islands and fountains in the four‑acre lake, and parking for 250 cars. The model and plan are used to explain circulation, vistas, and how Simpson Creek winds along 18 and into the property.

title: Clay model of the 'Grand Canyon' 8th hole
summary: James D. kneels over a clay model on the grass, explaining how the 8th green will be framed by a high wall, with a deep coal‑cinder bunker creating a 'Grand Canyon effect.' He notes that Pete Dye said most great holes lack such a frame and predicts this will be one of the most dramatic holes on the course.

title: 10. 1987–1988: Fine‑Tuning, Group Portraits & Course Maturity
chapter: 10. 1987–1988: Fine‑Tuning, Group Portraits & Course Maturity
summary: By 1987–88, the course is largely shaped. We see Steve Helmig building a mound on the right side of the 12th fairway to create a blind approach for safe tee shots. The Mazzee brothers and others build bridge abutments with rebar and concrete. Group portraits at the lake (timestamped 9.15.87) show James D., Jimmy, John Angotti, and other staff and pros lined up, laughing and chatting. Another winter 1988 segment shows James D. in a coat and hat explaining the high rock wall and cut at No. 9 and the surrounding wooded acreage. Scenic shots of autumn fairways, misty lakes, and dramatic valley holes (including the incomparable 16th and the magnificent 18th) show the course approaching its finished form, with stone walls, waterfalls, and framed vistas fully realized.

title: Louie presents a finished tape to Pete Dye
summary: In a later segment, Louie, jokingly called 'Cecil B. DeMille of Clarksburg,' hands a VHS tape to Pete Dye, saying the LaRosas requested he have it and that, 'unfortunately,' he must say again 'no charge.' Pete thanks him, and James D. says they value the photography because they’ll want to see it down through the years.

title: 11. Hole‑by‑Hole Narrated Slide/Video Tour (1–18)
chapter: 11. Hole‑by‑Hole Narrated Slide/Video Tour (1–18)
summary: The reel concludes with a structured, narrated tour of all 18 holes, using a combination of slides, plan views, and scenic footage. A professional‑sounding narrator (likely Harris Holt or a similar voice) reads a prepared description: No. 1 (400‑yard par 4 with safe right drive or long carry over eight traps), No. 2 (440‑yard par 4 over Simpson Creek), No. 3 (405‑yard par 4 with small target green), No. 4 (215‑yard par 3 along a huge stone wall), No. 5 (620‑yard par 5, true three‑shotter), No. 6 (345‑yard par 4 with tight drive and coal‑mine portal behind the green), No. 7 (155‑yard par 3 from elevated tee to shallow plateau), No. 8 (505‑yard par 5 with blind second and cavernous trap), No. 9 (465‑yard par 4 over Simpson Creek), No. 10 (450‑yard par 4 over waterfall and cliff), No. 11 (570‑yard par 5 with two landing areas), No. 12 (370‑yard par 4, potential world‑class drive‑and‑pitch), No. 13 (185‑yard par 3 similar to North Berwick’s Redan), No. 14 (440‑yard par 4 with natural stone wall), No. 15 (505‑yard par 5 with lake right and stone wall left), No. 16 (250‑yard par 3 over a breathtaking vista), No. 17 (430‑yard par 4 with rolling lies and bunkered green), and No. 18 (450‑yard par 4 over Simpson Creek with hillside gallery for 30,000 spectators). The narrator then signs off, and Louie Ellis, as 'film director and producer,' wishes viewers good night and 'God bless y’all.'

title: Narrated hole‑by‑hole tour crowns the project
summary: A professional voice narrates each hole’s yardage, par, and strategic character over slides and footage of the finished course, culminating in the 'magnificent 18th' with room for 30,000 spectators. The program ends with Louie Ellis signing off as film director and producer, wishing viewers good night and 'God bless y’all.'

title: 1. Cleaning Simpson Creek and Building Mowable Banks
chapter: 1. Cleaning Simpson Creek and Building Mowable Banks
summary: Jimmy LaRosa, introduced by an off‑camera "John," stands along Simpson Creek and explains the 1985 dredging operation. Footage shows a Michigan end loader driving in the creek, scooping silt and debris (sand, silt, coal fines, tires, bottles, cans) off a sandstone bottom and delivering it to a backhoe on the bank. From there, a chain of bulldozers—two D9s (Clarence Hebb and Tom Stamp) and a Komatsu 65 (Larry Reel)—push the wet material up the hillside to air‑dry. Jimmy explains that the dredged material will be reused to soften previously steep, un‑mowable banks so they can be grassed and maintained instead of planted in vines. Shots include concern for a large oak tree whose roots may be suffocating under added soil, and early views of a steel bridge recycled from Thornton, WV, that will serve golfers and maintenance crews.

title: End Loader Driving the Creek Like a Road
summary: A large Michigan end loader drives directly up Simpson Creek, bucket low in the water, using the solid sandstone bottom as a submerged roadway while Jimmy explains that it’s "almost like a highway under the water."

title: 2. Vision for a Navigable River and the 18th Hole
chapter: 2. Vision for a Navigable River and the 18th Hole
summary: On the future 18th fairway, Jimmy describes plans to make Simpson Creek navigable by building a 12‑foot dam downstream and removing obstructions like old bridge abutments. Workers jackhammer and load abutments with dynamite; Louie Ellis records the blast from under a truck, nervously joking while Bob Andrews and Frank Ketterman handle the shot. After the explosion, debris is gone and Jimmy points out a newly built redstone limestone wall at the 18th green, stone sourced from the Pittsburgh seam. He indicates the future clubhouse site above the green, where spectators will watch players finish 18 and see boats and fishermen on the river. He also explains a planned stone‑walled tee complex along the river, creating 440 yards of water left of the 18th tee as a visual intimidation, even though the actual carry is only about 100 feet.

title: 3. Number 5 Hole and Hydroseeding Work
chapter: 3. Number 5 Hole and Hydroseeding Work
summary: The camera moves to the future number 5 tee, where a Komatsu bulldozer (Jim Tonkery) shapes the "golden tee" on a 570‑yard hole. Jimmy directs Louie to pan from the tee across the corridor to a distant flag marking the green, reading a stake that says 260–265 yards to a landing area. He then has Louie do a 360‑degree pan to show Simpson Creek, now partially cleaned, and explains that the riverbed will eventually hold clear blue‑green water. A hydroseeder truck operated by Joe DeFazio (nozzle) and Arnold Chewing (driver) sprays seed and mulch on newly graded banks, stabilizing soil and beginning turf establishment.

title: Hydroseeding the Cleaned Banks
summary: A hydroseeder truck moves along the newly graded bank while Joe DeFazio stands on top with a hose, spraying seed and mulch high onto the slopes as Arnold Chewing drives. Jimmy explains how this will quickly green up and stabilize the banks.

title: 4. August 2 Blasting of Old Abutments and Rock Hump
chapter: 4. August 2 Blasting of Old Abutments and Rock Hump
summary: On August 2, 1985, Louie films as crews prepare to blast old abutments and a rock hump that create a dam effect in Simpson Creek. Equipment is shut down; Louie jokes about being told to get under a truck while still trying to film. A horn sounds, Frank Ketterman fires the shot, and a plume of debris rises. When the dust clears, the obstruction is gone. Jimmy later explains that holes were drilled 30 inches deep, six feet apart, and loaded with two pounds of dynamite each to remove the hump so future motorboats won’t strike it. Shot rock from the blast will be reused to build a two‑foot rock wall along a stream on number 6 fairway. The segment ends with Louie and John Nangotti signing off, noting the date.

title: Blasting Out Old Bridge Abutments
summary: All equipment falls silent as a horn sounds; Frank Ketterman fires the blast on old abutments in the creek. A plume of debris rises, then clears to reveal the obstruction gone. Louie, filming from under a truck, nervously jokes about wanting to see it while being told to run.

title: Louie’s Nervous Commentary During the Blast
summary: As they wait for the dynamite to go off, Louie Ellis talks to the camera: "I don't know what the hell I'm doing here… how in the hell you gonna take a movie and get under the truck?" His candid anxiety adds human texture to the otherwise technical construction record.

title: 5. August 9: Mapping Creek Cleanup Near Jimmy Joe’s House
chapter: 5. August 9: Mapping Creek Cleanup Near Jimmy Joe’s House
summary: On August 9, 1985, Louie films James D. and Jimmy LaRosa with their crew near Jimmy Joe’s house, about 500 feet upstream from active work. James D. explains that sulfur‑stained orange water from an old Consol mine will be piped below a future dam, while the main channel is cleaned and widened to create a 12‑foot‑deep navigable river from near the number 5 tee up to a natural ford. Backhoes and 631 scrapers remove topsoil and sediment from a nearly choked‑off bend, spreading it on flats that will become a sod farm. James D. points out a telephone pole painted orange marking a buried coaxial cable that must be located before deepening the channel. He brings former employee Tom Alexander on camera, praising his dirt‑moving skills, and shows the backhoe loading scrapers that haul material to drying areas.

title: 6. Rock Blasting and Reuse for Number 6 Wall
chapter: 6. Rock Blasting and Reuse for Number 6 Wall
summary: A few days later (August 12, 1985), footage shows a Caterpillar 245 backhoe loading shot rock from the creek into large rock trucks (ukes). James D. explains that a rock hump was blasted to even the riverbed and that the shot stone will be hauled to the number 6 fairway to build a rock wall along a stream, beautifying the area and using native material. The camera follows the backhoe scooping flat, wall‑worthy stones, dumping them into trucks, and then shows a D6 Caterpillar (operated by Christopher Reel) towing a loaded truck (driven by Tony Loria) up a steep, slick ramp out of the riverbed while Bob Andrews carefully hooks the cable. James D. notes the danger of cable snapping and the precautions taken. This sequence underscores the philosophy of reusing almost everything taken from the ground in the course’s construction.

title: Jimmy’s Vision of Boats Under the Clubhouse
summary: Standing on the 18th landing area, Jimmy describes a future where members in the clubhouse watch golfers finish 18 while also seeing people boating and fishing on a deep, clear Simpson Creek below, with six holes and the practice range visible from that vantage point.

title: 7. On‑Camera Narration: Explaining the Equipment Chain
chapter: 7. On‑Camera Narration: Explaining the Equipment Chain
summary: Multiple segments show Jimmy (and at times James D.) on camera with a microphone, standing by the entrance road and along Simpson Creek, giving a polished explanation of the entire sediment‑handling chain: the end loader in the creek, the backhoe on the bank, and three bulldozers (Clarence Hebb, Tom Stamp, Larry Reel) relaying material up the hillside to dry. He emphasizes that the dredged silt will be reused to soften steep banks, create mowable slopes, and make the hillside look more natural. He also points out a big oak tree that may be dying due to excess fill over its roots and mentions efforts to remove overburden to give the roots more oxygen. Shots alternate between his stand‑up narration, creek close‑ups (including sulfur‑stained water), graded banks, and workers in the creek (Joe DeFazio and Frank Ketterman) handling drainage and irrigation piping.

title: 8. 18th Fairway, Clubhouse View, and Entrance Rock Walls
chapter: 8. 18th Fairway, Clubhouse View, and Entrance Rock Walls
summary: From the landing area of the 18th fairway, Jimmy describes how blasting removed an old bridge abutment and rock hump, deepening the river so it now runs wide and clear instead of a foot deep over sediment. He points out a dramatic redstone limestone outcrop integrated into the 18th green at Pete Dye’s request and indicates the future clubhouse site above the green, where members will watch players finish 18 and see boats and fishermen on Simpson Creek, plus six holes and the practice range. He also shows rock recently placed along the entrance road and explains an experiment to build a rock wall there using the same stone as around the 18th green and lakes. Across the river, Tom Langston brush‑hogs tall weeds so Pete Dye can see the true ground contours for final fairway subtleties. Jimmy notes a shallow natural ford used for six years to cross the river and an orange‑flagged stake marking the future water level at 4.5 feet depth for boating. The segment ends with a new August 12 narration about removing rock from the riverbed and loading it into trucks for use on number 6, reinforcing the theme of using native materials.

title: D6 Towing a Loaded Rock Truck from the Riverbed
summary: A Caterpillar D6, operated by Christopher Reel, slowly pulls Tony Loria’s fully loaded rock truck up a steep, slick ramp out of the riverbed while Bob Andrews carefully hooks and signals the cable. The truck climbs without spinning its wheels, demonstrating careful coordination and power.

title: Restoring the Tipple and Laying the Mine Track (No. 10 Corridor)
chapter: Restoring the Tipple and Laying the Mine Track (No. 10 Corridor)
summary: The reel opens with John B.N. Gotti narrating as Louie films the old coal tipple and adjacent roadbed that will become a signature mining-themed corridor along the 10th hole. Workers (identified as Mike Ranzelli, Jack Oswald, Jack Dempsey and others) repair the tipple floor and lay narrow-gauge track on limestone ballast. Rusted mine cars are shown in detail, including stamped numbers used to credit miners. John explains that the cars will be filled with real coal from the property and parked on the track to separate the practice range from the 10th fairway and visually “turn” the hole. He points out where the clubhouse will stand in a clump of trees and where the rock base for the 10th tee sits on the opposite bank. Louie briefly stages himself swinging a sledgehammer on the track for laughs, and family/friends pose on the roadbed while John explains the theme and routing.
characters: Unidentified construction workers (Mike Ranzelli, Jack Oswald, Jack Dempsey, Larry Reel, Herb, etc.)

title: Integrating the Coal Tipple and Mine Cars into No. 10
summary: John stands on the roadbed beside the old coal tipple, explaining that restored tracks and authentic mine cars filled with coal from the property will separate the practice range from the 10th fairway and visually “turn” the hole. He points out where the clubhouse and 10th tee will sit relative to the tipple and roadbed.
characters: Unidentified construction workers (Mike Ranzelli, Jack Oswald, Jack Dempsey, Larry Reel, Herb, etc.)

title: Louie’s Sledgehammer Performance on the Track
summary: Wearing a dress shirt and tie, Louie theatrically swings a sledgehammer on the newly laid mine track while off-camera voices tease that he’s “never did a day’s work in his life” and is “overpaid at 33 cents an hour.”

title: Max Robinson and the Natural 16th Hole
summary: On the 16th par-3, John introduces Max Robinson as Pete Dye’s “eyes, ears, arms, and legs,” noting that the hole lies largely where it was naturally found. Max quietly predicts it will be one of the best holes on the course as Louie pans from green to tee to show its natural contours.

title: Utilities, Lakes, and No. 4 / No. 18 Construction
chapter: Utilities, Lakes, and No. 4 / No. 18 Construction
summary: Focus shifts to infrastructure and water features. A rural electrification crew lays three-phase cable in a trench to power the pump house for the No. 4 lake and an exhibition mine between holes 6 and 7. John identifies LaRosa Fuel’s man Larry Reel among the utility workers. On No. 4, he explains the lake’s aeration system, floating pump/fountain, and the plan to attract ducks and wildlife. Harris Holt and others describe burying electric lines to the lake and exhibition mine. On No. 18, Harris narrates topsoil spreading, fertilizer application that looks like “fog,” and seeding with a Chapel Valley mix (fescues and annual rye) to stabilize slopes. Heavy equipment (dozers, loaders, trucks) is shown moving topsoil from stockpiles to fairways, with James D. and Harris later walking viewers through the 18th fairway’s finished seedbed and adjacent 17th fairway and tees.
characters: Unidentified construction workers (Mike Ranzelli, Jack Oswald, Jack Dempsey, Larry Reel, Herb, etc.)

title: Louie’s ‘No Charge’ Monologue
summary: Louie steps in front of the camera to address Pete Dye directly, presenting the tape “the boys, the LaRosas, requested” and repeating that it’s “no charge” by orders. He jokes about having shelves of tapes labeled “LaRosa, LaRosa, LaRosa” and signs off with his trademark humor.

title: Touring Greens and Holes 3, 4, 11, 12, 16, and 7
chapter: Touring Greens and Holes 3, 4, 11, 12, 16, and 7
summary: John and Louie conduct a walking tour of several holes under construction. On No. 4, they show the par-3 green beside the three-and-a-half-acre lake, with mounding behind and a mine ventilation fan on the hill as a visual target. On No. 3 and No. 16 (a 250-yard par 3), John introduces cousin Andrew from Brooklyn and shaper Max Robinson, praising Max as Pete Dye’s “eyes, ears, arms, and legs” and predicting he’ll be a famous designer. They emphasize that No. 16 is largely a natural hole. On No. 11 (a 570-yard par 5), John highlights the elevated, man-made green and unique bunkering, noting how Max matched man-made contours to natural mounding. On No. 12, he explains Pete’s intent to give the hole a Scottish flavor with deep bunkers reminiscent of Scotland. Max prompts John to recount Pete Dye’s global portfolio (Japan, Dominican Republic, Switzerland, France) and his dominance in top-100 course rankings. Later, they visit the 7th hole’s mine-portal tee: the tee sits above a real mine portal, with orange flags marking a smaller, pear-shaped green Pete has ordered, and new cart paths and tees (gold and blue) relocated for better alignment and cart access up to the 8th tee mound.
characters: Unidentified construction workers (Mike Ranzelli, Jack Oswald, Jack Dempsey, Larry Reel, Herb, etc.)

title: Group Portraits and Professional Team on the 4th Fairway
chapter: Group Portraits and Professional Team on the 4th Fairway
summary: The footage includes several group shots of key project figures. On a finished or nearly finished 4th fairway beside the lake, James D. introduces his son James Jay (Jimmy), PB Dye, golf professional Drew Pearson, long-time surveyor Ed Tiefman, and shop operations coordinator John Angotti. Behind them, he points out the 4th green, mounding, the lake, the mine fan, and the hill apex Pete Dye aligned behind the green. Earlier, another group (in casual shirts and polos) poses near a pond and stone wall, while John continues narrating about the tipple, roadbed, and No. 10 tee. Louie steps in front of the camera to joke about never being paid since 1978 and about filming family weddings, while others vouch that he also didn’t charge for those. These scenes humanize the project, showing the LaRosa family, friends, and professional staff proud of the emerging course.
characters: Unidentified construction workers (Mike Ranzelli, Jack Oswald, Jack Dempsey, Larry Reel, Herb, etc.)

title: Coal Cinder Bunkers and Experimental Materials on No. 1
chapter: Coal Cinder Bunkers and Experimental Materials on No. 1
summary: James D. records a dated segment (October 6, 1987) on the 1st fairway explaining an experimental use of coal cinders in bunkers. He shows two truckloads of jet-black cinders from a wet-bottom utility furnace, noting their metallic sheen and black-green contrast against turf. A roll of fabric paper in the bunker base prevents mud from contaminating the cinders. He explains that seven large bunkers on No. 1 may each require about 20 tons of cinders. Harris Holt steps into the trap to test footing and ball lie, reporting that the cinders are quite soft; James speculates that rain and gravity may compact them over time. They discuss possibly mixing sand and cinders or going all-sand if playability is acceptable. This chapter captures the club’s willingness to experiment with materials that echo the site’s coal heritage.

title: James D. Explains Coal Cinder Bunkers
summary: Standing on the 1st fairway on October 6, 1987, James D. LaRosa explains the experimental use of jet-black coal cinders in bunkers, showing two truckloads of cinders and the first bunker filled with them. He discusses aesthetics, playability concerns, and the fabric layer used to keep mud from contaminating the cinders.

title: Seeding, Wildlife, and the 18th / 17th Complex
chapter: Seeding, Wildlife, and the 18th / 17th Complex
summary: Harris Holt narrates over views of the 18th fairway’s dark seedbed and adjacent lighter topsoil areas, explaining the seeding process: spring-tooth harrow, chain mat, seed, fertilizer, and rock phosphate, with no mulch needed at that time of year. He notes 5–10 inches of topsoil over good subsoil and a Chapel Valley mix of fescues and annual rye to quickly green the course and prevent erosion. The camera captures wild turkeys feeding on new grass on the 10th fairway, and Harris lists local wildlife—squirrels, wild turkey, deer, groundhog, fox, and ducks on Simpson Creek—remarking that foxes likely keep rabbits away. He points out the 18th green (recently planted), the 17th fairway and green, the 18th tees across the river, and a windmill installed as a visual target on No. 17. This section underscores the course’s emerging ecology alongside its construction.

title: Fountains, Mine Fans, and No. 4’s Finished Look
chapter: Fountains, Mine Fans, and No. 4’s Finished Look
summary: Attention returns to the 4th hole. James D. and Harris demonstrate the newly installed floating fountain in the No. 4 lake, describing its three-horsepower motor and sunburst spray pattern. They explain its dual purpose: aerating water to support fish and reduce algae, and providing aesthetic drama visible from the tees. James notes that triploid carp have been added to eat algae, cattails, and shoreline vegetation. He then directs Louie to pan up to the mine ventilation fan on the hill behind the green, explaining its real function in pulling methane and bad air from coal mines and how Pete Dye aligned it directly behind the flag as a star-shaped visual target. Pete also aligned the apex of the natural West Virginia hill behind the fan with the green, something James says “the Sovereign couldn’t duplicate.” This chapter shows how industrial artifacts and natural landforms are composed into a striking golf vista.

title: Fountain and Mine Fan Behind the 4th Green
summary: James D. and Harris switch on the new floating fountain in the 4th lake, then pan up to the star-shaped mine ventilation fan on the hill behind the green. James explains its real mining function and how Pete Dye aligned it and the hill’s apex behind the flag to create a unique mining-themed vista.

title: Mine Portal No. 7 Tee and Adjusting Greens & Tees
chapter: Mine Portal No. 7 Tee and Adjusting Greens & Tees
summary: The camera revisits the mine portal that serves as the 7th tee. John explains that the main tee is above the portal, with three additional tees down the right side. Orange flags mark Pete Dye’s changes to the 7th green, reducing its size and reshaping it into a pear form after deciding it was too easy. He points out the walk-off area to carts, the planned cart path up the hill, and the relocated gold and blue tees on the 8th tee mound, moved about 50 feet away from trees to create more room for the path and better alignment with the fairway. Survey stakes and small signs (e.g., “PAR 3 185 YDS 16 GREEN”) appear throughout, marking future greens and tees. This chapter captures the iterative nature of Dye’s design process and the detailed routing work done on-site.
characters: Unidentified construction workers (Mike Ranzelli, Jack Oswald, Jack Dempsey, Larry Reel, Herb, etc.)

title: Triploid Carp Stocking and Pond Ecology
chapter: Triploid Carp Stocking and Pond Ecology
summary: A substantial portion of the reel documents stocking triploid carp into the No. 1 and No. 4 lakes. James D. stands at the No. 1 lake with a box of fish (about 25 per bag), explaining that Gary Davis brought them from Pittsburgh after they were flown from Arkansas by breeder Bill Whiting. Bob Andrew and others pour lake water into the shipping bags to acclimate the fish and reduce shock. James notes that the carp are sterile, require state permission to import, won’t reproduce or bite hooks, and eat only green vegetation (algae, cattails, shoreline plants). He warns that if they escaped into streams and reproduced, they could upset ecological balance by stripping banks of vegetation. The men carefully release the fish, speculating about survival after the flight and drive, and James records the time and date (5:40 p.m., October 7) on camera. Similar procedures are repeated at the No. 4 lake. This chapter shows the club’s deliberate approach to water quality and environmental management.

title: Triploid Carp Stocking Ceremony
summary: At the No. 1 lake, James D., Gary Davis, and Bob Andrew carefully acclimate and release triploid carp from shipping bags into the water. James explains their Siberian origin, sterile status, and role in controlling algae and cattails, while Louie records the exact time and date for the record.

title: On-Camera Reflections: Roadbed, Clubhouse, and No. 10 Tee
chapter: On-Camera Reflections: Roadbed, Clubhouse, and No. 10 Tee
summary: In several stand-up segments dated October 6, 1987, John B.N. Gotti appears on camera (in a red cardigan and later in plaid flannel) with a microphone, summarizing the project for posterity. He explains that the roadbed beside the tipple will carry tracks and mine cars, that limestone ballast matches the original mine construction, and that Pete Dye insisted on laying the track exactly as before. He points out, often over B-roll of fairways and ponds, that a clump of trees at the end of the roadbed will host the clubhouse and that a rock base on the opposite bank is the No. 10 tee—“that’s where you start.” He repeatedly credits Louie Ellis as the “Clarksburg Cecil B. DeMille,” emphasizes that Louie works “no charge,” and jokes about having shelves full of tapes labeled “LaRosa.” These segments explicitly frame the footage as a historical record the LaRosas and Dyes will want to revisit in future years.

title: On-Camera Stand-Up: Roadbed, Clubhouse, and No. 10 Tee
summary: In a red cardigan with microphone in hand, John B.N. Gotti delivers a concise on-camera explanation of the roadbed, limestone ballast, future clubhouse in the trees, and the rock base that will be the No. 10 tee, explicitly framing the footage as something the LaRosas and Dyes will want to see “down through the years.”

title: Wildlife, Windmill, and Final Landscape Overview
chapter: Wildlife, Windmill, and Final Landscape Overview
summary: The reel closes with more polished landscape shots: the 4th green and lake with fountain, the 10th fairway corridor with roadbed and mine cars, the windmill and construction pad near the 17th/18th complex, and long views down valleys showing creeks, rock cuts, and shaped fairways. Harris and James D. talk about wild turkeys, ducks, deer, foxes, and other wildlife that have already begun using the course. The windmill is highlighted as a visual target on No. 17. The final shots of fountains, stone walls, and mounded fairways contrast sharply with the early raw earthmoving scenes, underscoring the transformation from stripped mine land to a fully realized Pete Dye golf landscape rooted in West Virginia’s coal heritage.

title: Opening: Land, Vision, and Dramatic Setting
chapter: Opening: Land, Vision, and Dramatic Setting
summary: The film opens with color bars and black, then a title card introducing the Pete Dye Golf Club, founder James D. LaRosa, designer Pete Dye, and the Burning Embers Resort in Clarksburg, West Virginia. A professional narrator describes Clarksburg and the 2,000-acre property as the perfect canvas for Pete Dye’s creativity. Aerial shots and scenic views of the valley, ponds, and early course shaping are intercut with an inset portrait of James D. LaRosa, who speaks in voiceover about his personal pride in building the project in his hometown and his belief in West Virginia’s potential for resort development. On-screen text quotes Pete Dye praising the property as the most dramatic he has ever seen, establishing the land’s uniqueness and the decade of labor invested by developer and designer.
characters: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)

title: Pete Dye’s Praise for the Property’s Drama
summary: Over sweeping aerial views of the valley and course corridors, on-screen text and audio present Pete Dye’s emphatic praise that he has never seen anything more dramatic than this piece of property, underscoring the uniqueness of the West Virginia site.

title: Pete Dye on Great Courses and the West Virginia Topography
chapter: Pete Dye on Great Courses and the West Virginia Topography
summary: Scenic shots of finished and in-progress holes, rivers, rockwork, and the reclaimed mining landscape play under extended commentary from Pete Dye. In circular inset interview footage, Dye, wearing his signature bucket hat, speaks at a microphone with a small group beside him. He explains that great golf courses often have dramatic natural features like oceans or mountains and argues that the topography of this part of West Virginia is equally irreplaceable. He contrasts it with flat regions like Illinois, Ohio, deserts, or Florida where topography must be manufactured. Dye emphasizes that at Pete Dye Golf Club every hole has a distinctive look, strong strategic variation (short, long, different), and a powerful surrounding atmosphere. He notes the coal mine background on some holes and the use of native rock, stressing that the course is now receiving the “small touches” that make it feel truly finished, unlike many rushed developments.
characters: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)

title: Finishing Touches, Number 4, and the Dramatic Arrival Experience
chapter: Finishing Touches, Number 4, and the Dramatic Arrival Experience
summary: Continuing in interview mode over sweeping course shots, Dye elaborates on what a “finished” golf course means to him. He criticizes projects that are opened for play after only six months of construction, arguing they are playable but not finished. He praises the ongoing rock work and detailing on hole 4, which he says has always been a great hole with a mountain backdrop but is only now visually reading as finished. He then describes routing the 18th hole back toward the clubhouse and how building the entrance road has created a powerful sense of atmosphere. Drawing a comparison to Augusta National’s Magnolia Drive, he claims the drive into Pete Dye Golf Club—from Smith Chapel, turning back along the entrance road—feels equally or even more impressive, making visitors feel they are “going to something.” He concludes that what has been created in the middle of West Virginia is “unheard of,” likening its appeal to, and even surpassing, established destinations like White Sulphur Springs, while being more accessible.
characters: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)

title: Dye’s Concept of a ‘Finished’ Golf Course
summary: In interview footage, Pete Dye contrasts rushed developments with his long-term approach, explaining that many courses open for play before they are truly finished. He praises the ongoing rock work and detailing on hole 4 and the course as a whole, emphasizing the importance of small touches that give each hole individual character.

title: Comparison to Augusta National’s Magnolia Drive
summary: Dye compares the entrance drive to Pete Dye Golf Club—starting at Smith Chapel and winding back to the clubhouse—to Augusta National’s Magnolia Drive, asserting that the drive into this course is equally, if not more, impressive and creates a powerful sense of going “to something.”

title: Transition to Technical Segment: Title and Hole-By-Hole Strategy Intro
chapter: Transition to Technical Segment: Title and Hole-By-Hole Strategy Intro
summary: After Dye’s atmospheric comparison, the film introduces a more technical section. A graphic title card appears: “Strategies & Variations of the 18 Holes” with the Pete Dye Golf Club emblem. The narrator frames the upcoming segment as a close-up look at the strategy and variation of all 18 holes designed by Pete Dye. This marks a shift from broad promotional storytelling and interview material to a structured, instructional walkthrough of the course layout.
characters: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)

title: Front Nine Strategy: Holes 1–9
chapter: Front Nine Strategy: Holes 1–9
summary:
Using a detailed routing map and a pointer, the narrator walks through the front nine. For each hole, the camera focuses on the drawn fairways, greens, water features, and Simpson Creek, while the narrator gives yardages, pars, and strategic advice:
- Hole 1 (397-yard par 4, dogleg left): Introduced as a preview of the course’s excitement, challenge, and natural beauty.
- Hole 2 (439-yard par 4, dogleg left): Tee shot crosses Simpson Creek; strategy is to stay left to open the second shot (around a six-iron) into the green.
- Hole 3 (367-yard par 4, slight dogleg right): Typical play is three-wood and eight-iron to a small green; grass mounds in front punish short approaches.
- Hole 4 (215-yard par 3 over a rock-lined lake): A visually beautiful, strategic par 3 where the front is open, allowing players to run the ball in.
- Hole 5 (628-yard par 5, dogleg right): Described as a “monster” hole; players can cut the corner over Simpson Creek on the third shot to save about 30 yards if they dare.
- Hole 6 (341-yard par 4, straightaway): The shortest par 4, but a very tight driving hole demanding an accurate tee shot to the right of a walled stream bed; a coal mine portal is visible behind the green, and players must pass through a real coal mine for 140 feet to reach the 7th tee.
- Hole 7 (155-yard par 3): Played from an elevated tee above a coal mine portal; surrounding mounding creates an unusual yet fair hole.
- Hole 8 (504-yard par 5, dogleg left): The only hole where the green is not visible from the tee; a hidden 1.5-acre bunker awaits sliced second shots.
- Hole 9 (465-yard par 4, dogleg right): Called “awesome,” requiring a 180-yard carry over Simpson Creek from an elevated tee and then at least a two-iron to a three-tiered green protected by bunkers.
The visuals remain focused on the map, with occasional cutaways to course features, while the narration is purely strategic and descriptive.
characters: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)

title: Coal Mine Integration and Tunnel Between Holes 6 and 7
summary: The narrator explains that after playing the tight par-4 6th hole, with a coal mine portal visible behind the green, players must pass through a real coal mine for 140 feet to reach the 7th tee, visually tying the course to its mining heritage.
characters: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)

title: Back Nine Strategy Part 1: Holes 10–13
chapter: Back Nine Strategy Part 1: Holes 10–13
summary:
The map-based walkthrough continues for the early back nine, with the narrator describing each hole’s character and strategy while the pointer traces the routing:
- Hole 10 (450-yard par 4, dogleg right): A spectacular, ominous-looking hole where a string of coal mine cars turns the hole off the drive and a 25-foot vertical waterfall guards the green’s right side. Despite its appearance, it is described as fair, with a bailout area left of the green.
- Hole 11 (570-yard par 5, slight dogleg left): Extremely wide, offering ample room and recovery opportunities for errant shots.
- Hole 12 (370-yard par 4, straightaway): Strategy is to avoid going too far right; a large camelback-shaped mound can leave players blind to the green, making it a potential birdie or bogey hole.
- Hole 13 (185-yard par 3): The view is called breathtaking, “Mother nature at her greatest,” and the hole is compared to the famous Redan hole in Scotland. It slopes front-to-back and right-to-left, with a large bunker behind the green.
The visuals remain on the routing map, occasionally zooming in on individual holes as the narrator emphasizes both natural beauty and strategic nuance.
characters: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)

title: Hole 10’s Coal Cars and Waterfall
summary: The narrator describes the 10th hole as a spectacular 450-yard par 4 where a string of coal mine cars turns the hole off the drive and a 25-foot vertical waterfall protects the green, blending industrial heritage with dramatic golf design.
characters: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)

title: Back Nine Strategy Part 2: Holes 14–16
chapter: Back Nine Strategy Part 2: Holes 14–16
summary:
The narrator continues the hole-by-hole description for the mid-to-late back nine, again using the course map and pointer:
- Hole 14 (440-yard par 4, dogleg right): Tees are elevated directly above the landing area, and the entire hole is framed by a stone wall, evoking “shades of Scotland.” It is described as a potential birdie hole.
- Hole 15 (505-yard par 5, slight dogleg right): From the tee, players see a magnificent view with a 10-acre lake bordering the right side. The second shot will “flirt with the water,” emphasizing risk–reward along the lake.
- Hole 16 (250-yard downhill par 3, “the incomparable 16th”): A long downhill par 3 where the tee shot carries over an expansive fairway to a green plateaued on the right. A bailout area short and left allows for an easier pitch if players choose safety over aggression.
The map zooms in on these holes, particularly highlighting the stone wall framing 14, the large lake on 15, and the dramatic downhill nature of 16, reinforcing the course’s visual drama and strategic variety.
characters: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)

title: Closing Holes and Tournament Ambition: Holes 17–18 and Final Pitch
chapter: Closing Holes and Tournament Ambition: Holes 17–18 and Final Pitch
summary:
The film concludes with descriptions of the final two holes and a summative promotional message. Over continued map imagery and scenic shots, the narrator explains:
- Hole 17 (430-yard par 4): A slightly uphill drive leads to potentially downhill lies due to rolling terrain. The green is large enough to hold approach shots but is well bunkered.
- Hole 18 (450-yard par 4, “the magnificent 18th”): From an elevated tee, players drive across Simpson Creek, which borders the left side of the fairway. The second shot comes from an ample landing area, but players must favor the left side to have an open approach to the green. The right side is a contoured hillside designed to accommodate up to 30,000 spectators, explicitly evoking dreams of hosting major tournaments.
The narrator closes by stating that the vision of James LaRosa and the genius of Pete Dye have combined to create a unique opportunity in central West Virginia, and thanks viewers for sharing in the excitement. The final tone is aspirational, positioning the club as both a world-class golf experience and a potential major championship venue.
characters: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)

title: Spectator Hill on the 18th for Major Tournaments
summary: In describing the 18th hole, the narrator notes that the right side of the fairway is a contoured hillside capable of holding up to 30,000 spectators, explicitly linking the design to ambitions of hosting major tournaments in central West Virginia.
characters: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)

title: Opening titles and introduction (Louie’s film for Pete)
chapter: Opening titles and introduction (Louie’s film for Pete)
summary: Simple title and credit cards (“PETE DYE GOLF CLUB”; “DIRECTOR / PRODUCER / LOUIE ELLIS”) introduce the tape as Louie Ellis’s production. This frames the footage as a deliberate, authored record of the course for Pete Dye and the LaRosa family.

title: On‑course intro with Jim and dogs – Gold tee overview
chapter: On‑course intro with Jim and dogs – Gold tee overview
summary: The narrator stands on a finished or nearly finished tee (gold tee) on a par‑4, 465‑yard dogleg right. He addresses “Jim” (James D. LaRosa) and notes family in the background. Two dogs run around. From an elevated vantage, he describes the fairway, a bunker at 240 yards, and the beauty of the trees, especially in fall. He then has Louie pan to show the gold tee’s boulder retaining wall and the built‑up blue tee below, explaining that many man‑hours and ingenuity went into constructing it. He points out Simpson Creek below and additional tees (white, red, ladies) along the right, and a distinctive rock that looks like a golf club near the end of hole #2.
characters: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

title: Hole #2 from above – Simpson Creek and multi‑tee strategy
chapter: Hole #2 from above – Simpson Creek and multi‑tee strategy
summary: From high ground near the end of #2, the narrator explains that #2 is a dogleg left. Players must drive over Simpson Creek to a landing area and can “eat off as much as you want” of the creek/dogleg: the more you bite off, the shorter the second shot. He notes that the right side of the fairway has been sodded for easier maintenance. The camera shows construction equipment, raw graded areas, and the creek valley. He emphasizes the multiple tee sets (gold, blue, white, red, ladies) and how they align along the right side above Simpson Creek.
characters: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

title: Entering the 8th hole canyon – coal seam and strip‑mine wall
chapter: Entering the 8th hole canyon – coal seam and strip‑mine wall
summary: The focus shifts to the dramatic par‑5 8th hole, carved into a former strip‑mine high wall. Standing about 115 yards from the flag in what will be a grass bunker, the narrator describes a 500‑yard par‑5 with a long sand bunker running to the green, a stone wall and stream behind the green, and a berm that may stop balls before the water. He points out the exposed Pittsburgh seam of coal—about eight feet thick—at the base of a 70‑foot high wall, with another 60–70 feet of trees above, creating a 120–130 foot vertical canyon. He explains that the bunker is about 315 yards off the tee, so it’s mainly a second‑shot hazard. The camera shows the coal seam, the towering wall, and active topsoil dumping and grading on the upper level, with plans to seed soon.
characters: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

title: Explaining the 8th hole’s coal‑seam canyon
summary: Standing in the future grass bunker on #8, the narrator shows the exposed Pittsburgh seam of coal and the towering strip‑mine high wall, describing how Pete directed them to strip the overburden to create a “Grand Canyon” feel. He quantifies the wall’s height and explains how a sliced second shot will end up in the canyon bunker.
characters: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

title: Shaping the 8th green and acre‑plus bunker – drainage and coal seam
chapter: Shaping the 8th green and acre‑plus bunker – drainage and coal seam
summary: Walking closer to the 8th green, the narrator discusses an open drainage ditch along the coal seam that Pete suggested might remain open for seepage water. He notes the fairway will be 40 yards wide, the bunker 60 yards wide—over 100 yards before the ditch. From about 30 yards short of the flag, he shows a grass bunker in front of the green, mounding and bunkering for water control, and how close the green edge comes to the coal wall (about 30 feet). He points out steep contours on the left of the green and sand bunkers 20 feet above the green on the hillside. He repeatedly asks Pete to review the film and advise by phone where the green edges and depressions should be. Pete’s dog “Bunker/Brutus” appears around the green and in the big acre‑plus bunker. The narrator has Louie pan up the wall to show its full 130–150 foot height and the canyon feel from the bunker floor. Trucks dump topsoil behind the green, and he shows a deep mine opening into the Pittsburgh seam, contrasting deep mining with strip mining and calling the seam “the most single valuable mineral deposit in the world.”
characters: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

title: Documenting the 8th green for Pete’s remote approval
summary: From 30–60 feet around the 8th green, the narrator carefully walks Louie through the contours, depressions, and proximity to the coal wall, repeatedly saying “I hope you can see this, Pete” and asking Pete to tell them over the phone where to adjust the green edge and drainage ditch. Pete’s dog Bunker wanders through the shots, humanizing the technical walkthrough.
characters: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

title: Integrating mining history into the course narrative
summary: Near the mine portal and coal seam, the narrator explains that the Pittsburgh seam is “the most single valuable mineral deposit in the world,” running from Pittsburgh to near Clarksburg. He contrasts deep mining (the portal) with strip mining (the high wall) and says this will give “another dimension to coal mining to this whole golf course,” explicitly tying local industrial history into the course’s identity.
characters: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

title: Behind and beside the 8th green – cart paths, 9th tee rock, and canyon scale
chapter: Behind and beside the 8th green – cart paths, 9th tee rock, and canyon scale
summary: From behind the 8th green, about 30 feet behind the flag, the narrator shows the green’s contour, the coal seam just beyond, and disturbed areas where irrigation piping has altered the shape and must be re‑shaped. He points out the cart path behind a mound, the planned cart parking area, and the route down to the 9th tee. A large single standing rock marks the 9th tee location and visually separates #8 from #9. Then the camera moves to the left edge of #8, looking across the cavernous bunker. The narrator jokes that you could hide “20 D9s” (bulldozers) in there and notes that Jim, seen in the distance, gets smaller and smaller as he walks into the bunker, emphasizing its scale. Harris Holt gives an exact yardage (102 yards) from the fairway to the green. The narrator explains the contouring: mounds and bunkers 20–25 feet above the green on the left, multiple levels that ensure a second shot will finish somewhere visible rather than lost.
characters: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

title: Revealing the scale of the acre‑plus bunker on #8
summary: From the left edge of #8, the camera watches Jim walk into the massive grass/sand bunker until he becomes tiny. The narrator jokes you could hide “20 D9s” in there and notes that the bunker is partly grass, partly sand, giving a dramatic sense of the hole’s scale and intimidation factor.
characters: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

title: Harris Holt’s precise yardage and the ‘can’t lose it’ second shot
summary: Standing 102 yards from the 8th green (per Harris Holt’s measurement), the narrator explains the contouring that ensures a second shot will always finish in a visible area: “the ball’s going to be in here somewhere… can be seen.” This highlights a design philosophy of fairness despite the hole’s dramatic setting.
characters: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

title: Fine‑tuning 8th approach contours – multiple vantage points for Pete
chapter: Fine‑tuning 8th approach contours – multiple vantage points for Pete
summary: The team methodically documents the approach into #8 from various distances and elevations for Pete’s review. From about 45 yards, then 35 yards, then 35–40 yards from the pin but higher up near the bunkers, they show the two flat “landing” shelves and the drop‑offs between them. The narrator stresses that on the second shot “the ball’s going to be in here somewhere… can be seen,” which he calls unusual and desirable. He repeatedly says they hope Pete can see enough on film to tell them what to do over the phone. A dog named “Bogey” wanders into frame. They then climb up to the bunkers above the fairway to give Pete a high‑angle view back over the huge bunker and approach, hoping Pete will say “leave everything as it is.” The narrator jokes that Louie would say “are you kidding?” but insists the views should give Pete a good sense of the shaping.
characters: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

title: Louie’s sign‑off to Pete and panoramic views from above #8
chapter: Louie’s sign‑off to Pete and panoramic views from above #8
summary: From high ground above #8, looking down toward #3, the narrator calls it “another beautiful Pete Dye job” and says “this is what the golfer sees.” We see Jim and his family heading to their “dogmobile” (a vehicle loaded with dogs); Jim honks the horn. Louie takes the microphone and speaks directly to Pete, saying it was nice doing the job and joking that with Harris Holt, James D., and Louie Ellis “how in the hell can you go wrong.” He adds “God bless you” and calls Jim “the boss of all bosses” who “worked the hell out of me today.” The narrator then captures another view of the hole as the sun angle changes, saying nobody expects such a dramatic course in Clarksburg and praising Pete’s “beautiful job.”
characters: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

title: Louie Ellis’s heartfelt sign‑off to Pete Dye
summary: High above #8, after extensive filming, Louie takes the mic and speaks directly to Pete: he says it was nice doing the job, jokes that with Harris Holt, James D., and himself “how in the hell can you go wrong,” and notes that Jim “worked the hell out of me today.” The narrator adds that Louie, with a bad hip, walked the ground for Pete, and that he and his wife Nancy send their regards.
characters: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

title: Stone‑built ‘big boy’ tees and finished views of #9
chapter: Stone‑built ‘big boy’ tees and finished views of #9
summary: The camera returns to the stacked boulder retaining walls supporting the upper tees, which the narrator calls the “big boy tees.” He wants a close‑up so others can appreciate the work that went into them. He then pans down to the blue tees and across the surrounding trees. The footage includes more polished, grassed views of a fairway and green (identified as #9), with the sun now at a different angle than earlier in the day. The narrator notes that the changed light gives a different view and perspective of #9 and the surrounding trees, underscoring the course’s beauty in varying conditions.
characters: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

title: Showcasing the ‘big boy’ tees and stonework
summary: The camera lingers on massive stacked boulder walls supporting the upper tees, which the narrator calls the “big boy tees.” He wants a close‑up so others can appreciate the work and ingenuity that went into building them, underscoring the physical and aesthetic investment in the tee complexes.
characters: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

title: Strategic explanation of Hole #2 over Simpson Creek
summary: From an elevated view over #2, the narrator explains that players must drive over Simpson Creek to a landing spot and can “eat off as much as you want” of the creek/dogleg, with risk‑reward implications for the second shot. He praises #2 as a beautiful dogleg left and notes that every hole is well designed, giving Pete’s routing and strategy clear credit.
characters: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

title: Raw construction montages – tees, fairways, coal walls, and mine portal
chapter: Raw construction montages – tees, fairways, coal walls, and mine portal
summary: Intercut throughout the tape are extended sequences of raw construction: graded dirt basins, steep cut banks, stacked boulder walls, exposed coal seams, and a rectangular deep‑mine portal framed in the cut face. Dump trucks unload topsoil; CASE bulldozers and other heavy equipment grade slopes and fairways. Stakes, pipes, and drainage ditches mark future greens, bunkers, and cart paths. The narrator overlays these visuals with descriptions of the gold and blue tees, the par‑4 dogleg right with a 240‑yard bunker, Simpson Creek below, and the multi‑tee system (white, red, ladies). He repeatedly emphasizes the “Grand Canyon” feeling of the 8th hole canyon, the difficulty of mowing 60‑foot banks, and the uniqueness of integrating the Pittsburgh seam of coal and mining history into the course. These sequences serve as a technical record of earthmoving and infrastructure before turf and finishing.
characters: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

title: Closing perspective shots and black‑frame transitions
chapter: Closing perspective shots and black‑frame transitions
summary: The tape ends with additional narrated views of a fairway (likely #9) and surrounding trees, with the narrator remarking on how the sun’s changed position gives a different perspective. Some sections are black frames with only audio, likely tape gaps or in‑camera edits, but the narration continues to reference the gold tee, boulders, dogleg right, and bunker at 240 yards. The overall close emphasizes the course’s visual richness and the pride in the construction work, leaving Pete with multiple angles to review.
characters: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

title: Ellis Productions Intro & Venue Establishment
chapter: Ellis Productions Intro & Venue Establishment
summary: The tape opens with a playful self‑introduction by cameraman Louis P. Ellis, posing in a red blazer with his shoulder‑mounted camera and a director’s chair embroidered with his name and title. A close‑up of an Ellis Productions business card follows, listing video services and contact information in Clarksburg, WV. The scene then cuts to a nighttime exterior of a neon “Green Acres” sign, establishing the venue for the August 21, 1993 dinner and party.

title: Louis Ellis’s Playful Director Intro
summary: Louis P. Ellis appears in a red blazer with a shoulder‑mounted camera, standing behind a director’s chair embroidered “FILM DIRECTOR & PRODUCER LOUIS P. ELLIS,” and verbally introduces himself and the event.

title: Credit to Pam Iquina and Employees
summary: Over shots of the buffet and throughout the early audio, Louis repeatedly states that the August 21, 1993 dinner was “prepared by Pam Iquina and employees,” explicitly acknowledging the staff’s work.

title: Arrival, Bar Mingling, and Band Setup
chapter: Arrival, Bar Mingling, and Band Setup
summary: Inside Green Acres, timestamped 7:18–7:19 PM, guests in semi‑formal attire mingle at the bar and around tables. Louis greets people warmly (“Hi Nancy. Pretty girl.” “Hi honey. Nice dinner tonight.”), comments on being full from dinner, and encourages his companion to stay and hear the band. The camera alternates between the bar, dining tables, and the small stage where musicians and crew set up drums, keyboards, and cables. Staff move through the room, and Louis jokes about “my lawyer, December G. Mousefield” as he circulates. Close‑ups of guests, including a woman with dark curly hair and pearls, begin to personalize the crowd.

title: Buffet, Chef Action Station, and Food Spread
chapter: Buffet, Chef Action Station, and Food Spread
summary: The focus shifts to the culinary side of the evening. Louis repeatedly credits “dinner prepared by Pam Iquina and employees” while filming buffet pans piled with shrimp, lemon wedges, and other hot items under warm lighting. A chef in full whites and toque works at a live cooking station, stirring pans and plating food. These shots visually reinforce Louis’s praise of the “good spread” and highlight the staff’s effort behind the event.

title: On‑Stage Remarks by the Woman in the Sequined Dress
chapter: On‑Stage Remarks by the Woman in the Sequined Dress
summary: Attention moves to the front of the room. A man in a suit appears at a microphone near a decorative fountain, then the woman in the black sequined dress joins him on or near the stage. She eventually stands alone at the mic, gesturing, waving, and interacting with the audience, likely giving remarks, a toast, or an introduction for the band. Floral arrangements and keyboards frame her, underscoring a semi‑formal program segment within the otherwise casual evening.
characters: Woman in black sequined dress (possible emcee/host)

title: On‑Stage Moment with the Sequined‑Dress Woman
summary: A woman in a black sequined dress stands at the microphone on stage, gesturing and engaging the audience, framed by floral arrangements and band equipment, signaling a semi‑formal program within the party.
characters: Woman in black sequined dress (possible emcee/host)

title: Band Performance and Early Dancing
chapter: Band Performance and Early Dancing
summary: The live band begins playing. Louis films the keyboardist, drummer, bassist, and at times a male vocalist on stage, then turns to the dance floor where the first couples start slow‑dancing under a chandelier. He continues to chat with his companion about the dinner and jokes about being ready to play golf, tying the social event back to the club context. Couples of various ages fill the floor, and Louis’s camera weaves between tables and dancers, capturing both the band and the growing crowd on the floor.

title: First Couples Take the Floor
summary: As the band plays, the first couples begin slow‑dancing under the chandelier, transitioning the evening from dinner and speeches into full social dancing.

title: Running Joke: “My Lawyer, December G. Mousefield”
summary: While filming guests near the bar and dance floor, Louis jokingly points someone out as “my lawyer, December G. Mousefield,” then repeats “There’s my lawyer,” adding humor and a sense of inside jokes among attendees.

title: Dinner‑Dance in Full Swing: Couples and Crowd Atmosphere
chapter: Dinner‑Dance in Full Swing: Couples and Crowd Atmosphere
summary: The heart of the tape is an extended montage of the dinner‑dance at full capacity. Couples in suits and dresses slow‑dance closely beneath the chandelier while tables with candles and glassware frame the edges. Louis’s audio is dominated by repeated greetings (“Nice to meet you”) and playful asides (“There’s my lawyer, December G. Mousefield”), suggesting he is being introduced around as he films. The same couples and individuals recur from different angles—an older man in a light jacket with a blonde partner, a woman in a light pantsuit raising her arms enthusiastically, a woman in a striped dress, and a woman in a wide‑brimmed hat—building a sense of a tight‑knit, multi‑generational club community enjoying the band and each other’s company.

title: Crowded Dance Floor Under the Chandelier
summary: A wide shot shows the dance floor packed with couples of various ages in suits and dresses, swaying in unison beneath a large chandelier, with candlelit tables at the edges—an iconic image of the club’s social life.

title: Dense Mingling, Introductions, and Candid Reactions
chapter: Dense Mingling, Introductions, and Candid Reactions
summary: The camera moves off and on the dance floor into denser clusters of guests. Many shots show people shoulder‑to‑shoulder, talking, laughing, and occasionally reacting directly to the camera. Louis’s audio becomes a near‑continuous loop of “Nice to meet you,” overlaid on music and chatter, as he pans across faces and backs, capturing a receiving‑line‑like sequence of introductions. Several individuals recur—a woman in a light top and patterned skirt, a man in a dark jacket near her, a woman in a light patterned dress, and a man in a light shirt—giving continuity to the crowd. The final seconds fade to black, indicating a pause or end of this raw segment.

title: Candid Guest Reactions to the Camera
summary: In several close shots, individual guests—such as a woman with medium‑length light hair in a light dress—turn toward the camera mid‑laugh or mid‑sentence, reacting spontaneously to being filmed.

title: Black Screen Transition / Tape Break
chapter: Black Screen Transition / Tape Break
summary: The last visible portion of this analyzed segment is largely black screen, likely representing a camera pause, lens cap, or end of this particular scene on the tape. Ambient audio may continue briefly, but no new visual content appears. This functions as a natural break before the tape moves on to other material (elsewhere on the archive, the narrator begins to talk about “the construction” or “conception” of the Golf Club, but that audio is not visually supported here).

title: TV Sports Feature & Visual Intro to Pete Dye Golf Club
chapter: TV Sports Feature & Visual Intro to Pete Dye Golf Club
summary: A local TV sports anchor introduces the Pete Dye Golf Club’s opening after a decade in the making. Scenic B‑roll shows fairways, water features, the mine portal by a green, and a massive acre‑and‑a‑half bunker. A construction‑era photo and Pete Dye’s signature letter appear, along with a routing map. Bill Pulice, Director of Marketing, gives an on‑camera soundbite about each hole feeling private and the course becoming “your favorite place.” The sequence then cross‑fades into early‑morning clubhouse dining‑room shots dated July 3, 1993, setting up the internal ceremonies.

title: Indoor Breakfast Meeting – 15‑Year Journey & Mission Statement
chapter: Indoor Breakfast Meeting – 15‑Year Journey & Mission Statement
summary: In a clubhouse breakfast setting (timestamped 7/3/93), a gray‑haired man in a striped polo—likely Jimmy LaRosa—addresses members and early stakeholders. He recounts that the project began 15 years earlier, notes Pete Dye’s absence due to a family retreat at Culver, Indiana, and relays Dye’s apologies and promise to return. He credits “the great architect in the sky” and Mother Nature for the land, and reads the club’s mission: to establish an international club of unparalleled stature, to honor the architect’s genius, to uphold golf’s traditions, and to be a model of successful club management. Attendees eat breakfast, shake hands, and listen attentively as he recognizes his father and other contributors.

title: Small‑Room Leadership Huddle – Gratitude & Future Focus
chapter: Small‑Room Leadership Huddle – Gratitude & Future Focus
summary: In a smaller dining/meeting room, Jimmy LaRosa (probable) and a few core figures (including an older man in a striped golf shirt and another in a green polo) share an intimate recognition moment. The same themes are repeated in a more informal tone: Pete Dye sends his regards, is at a family retreat, and loves the property; God and Mother Nature are credited as the ultimate architects. The group laughs, claps, and gestures as the speaker pivots from the 15‑year struggle to what the club will become going forward.

title: Formal Introduction of Director of Golf Jim Jamieson
chapter: Formal Introduction of Director of Golf Jim Jamieson
summary: Back in a larger dining/bar area, Jimmy LaRosa (probable) formally introduces Director of Golf Jim Jamieson. He lists Jamieson’s PGA Tour accomplishments—Western Open champion, high finishes in the Masters and PGA Championship, Quad Cities Open winner—and praises his character. Jamieson thanks the LaRosa family, calls the property unique, and dreams aloud about hosting celebrity events, a tour event, even Ryder Cup‑type competitions. He outlines the day’s special opening‑day format: first nine as two‑best‑ball, second nine as scramble, playing from different tees (Miners, Senior, Dye, Championship, Professional). He explains the dual handicap system (traveling vs. membership) and jokes about “phony handicaps,” then gives course‑care instructions and notes that the 8th green and fairway are still maturing.

title: Mission & Objectives of Pete Dye Golf Club Read Aloud
summary: In the breakfast meeting, the club leader reads a formal mission statement: to establish an international club of unparalleled stature, to honor Pete Dye’s genius, to uphold golf’s traditions, and to be a model of successful club management. The room listens quietly, underscoring the seriousness of the project’s ambitions.

title: Introduction of Director of Golf Jim Jamieson
summary: Jimmy LaRosa introduces Jim Jamieson, listing his PGA Tour victories and major‑championship finishes, then jokes that “besides all that, he’s just a great guy.” Jamieson thanks the LaRosa family and talks about bringing in celebrity events and possibly a Ryder Cup‑style event.

title: Member Roll‑Call & Club Culture in the Dining Room
chapter: Member Roll‑Call & Club Culture in the Dining Room
summary: After Jamieson’s briefing, the speaker asks everyone to stand and introduce themselves so members know who they’re playing with. One by one, men and a few women state their names, hometowns, and brief comments: Raymond Pizzillo calls the course a “mountain masterpiece”; Louie Bonasso notes he’s on the board of this “soon‑to‑be internationally renowned club”; others hail from Fairmont, Bridgeport, Morgantown, Austin, Dallas, Indiana (PA), Raleigh, Dallas, Washington, D.C., Ireland (assistant pro Patrick Garrity), and more. The Board of Governors—Lloyd Bonasso, Tom Amon, Steve Savodnik—is acknowledged. There’s light teasing (“I’m one of Jimmy’s outlaws”) and anticipation (“I’ve waited 15 years”). The tone is collegial and aspirational, cementing the club’s identity as both local and national in reach.

title: Pre‑Round Logistics, Marketing & Word‑of‑Mouth Push
chapter: Pre‑Round Logistics, Marketing & Word‑of‑Mouth Push
summary: As breakfast wraps, Jamieson and the club leadership encourage members to help grow the club by inviting friends—“nothing works like word of mouth.” They mention caddies being used as spotters due to wet conditions and urge careful cart use. They thank Pat, Pam, and staff for breakfast and credit “Billy Pulice” for handling most of the membership marketing. Members are encouraged to bring potential members to any of the three leaders for information. The group then disperses toward carts to begin the day’s play.

title: First Member Play Day – Carts, Tee‑Off & Louie’s Commentary
chapter: First Member Play Day – Carts, Tee‑Off & Louie’s Commentary
summary: Home‑video style footage shows rows of carts and members heading out for the inaugural member play day (timestamped 7/3/93). Louie Ellis and Harris Holt banter as they film carts rolling by, joking about “we got their cart” and calling late arrivals “the last two, but the most important.” On the first tee, James D. LaRosa hits “right down the middle,” followed by “JJ” (Jimmy Joe/LaRosa) hitting his first drive on his own golf course. Clergy (“Monsignor,” “Father Ken”) tee off, with Louie joking about aiming for the waterfall. Louie and Harris capture multiple groups on various tees and greens, narrating shots, distances, and mishaps with affectionate humor. The course’s dramatic features—waterfalls, stone walls, creeks, huge bunkers—are repeatedly framed as players test the new layout.

title: First Tee – James D. & JJ Play Their Own Course
summary: On the first tee of the new course, James D. LaRosa hits “right down the middle,” followed by JJ (Jimmy Joe) hitting his first drive on the course he helped build. Louie’s commentary emphasizes that this is JJ’s first time playing his own golf course, making the moment feel like a personal culmination of years of work.

title: On‑Course Play – Members, Bets & Friendly Needling
chapter: On‑Course Play – Members, Bets & Friendly Needling
summary: Louie and Harris roam the course, filming tee shots, approaches, and putts on holes 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, and 8. They call out players by name—Raymond Pizzillo, Sam Oliverio, Bobby Farrell, Ralph Sutton, Danny DeMarino—and describe lies, distances, and hazards (“Everything on this side of that stone wall is rough… there’s a little creek that runs down through there”).
