Friendly wagers are in play (“We’re playing for a quarter a hole; I’ve got him down one already”), and one player jokes that he withdrew his bet so he doesn’t owe a quarter. They tease each other about intimidation and “El Diablo” working on the first tee. The commentary is light, self‑deprecating, and full of inside jokes, capturing the club’s early social fabric as much as the golf.

title: Louie & Harris as ‘Cecil B. DeMille’ and ‘Otto Preminger’
chapter: Louie & Harris as ‘Cecil B. DeMille’ and ‘Otto Preminger’
summary: In a playful on‑camera bit, two men—almost certainly Louie Ellis and Harris Holt—pose as famous directors “Cecil B. DeMille” and “Otto Preminger.” One says he’s been videoing the course since 1978 as a “non‑paid member” and praises James D. and Jimmy Joe as “two beautiful people.” The other calls the site “God’s country” and says he’s never had so much pleasure making a film. They joke about the camera still rolling and about this being “the only video you get in the world without charge, right Louie? As long as Nancy says okay, it’s okay.” This meta‑segment explicitly acknowledges the long‑term amateur documentation that underpins the archive.

title: Louie & Harris as ‘Cecil B. DeMille’ and ‘Otto Preminger’
summary: Louie and Harris stage a mock interview as famous film directors, with Louie noting he’s been filming the course since 1978 as a “non‑paid member” and praising James D. and Jimmy Joe as “two beautiful people.” The bit is humorous but also reveals the depth of Louie’s long‑term commitment to documenting the project.

title: More Member Golf – Par‑3s, Wild Pants & Course Features
chapter: More Member Golf – Par‑3s, Wild Pants & Course Features
summary: Louie continues filming on holes 4, 5, 7, and 17. He highlights a “beautiful par 3,” comments on Mike Delaney’s flamboyant pants, and notes distances (“Ray, 135 yards from here”). Shots into creeks, over stone walls, and from bunkers illustrate Pete Dye’s rugged design. Louie admires the clarity of the water and jokes about balls floating there. He films Jim Jamieson hitting a near‑perfect shot on a par‑3 and speculates about the first hole‑in‑one. The camera lingers on scenic vistas—lakes between holes, waterfalls, and long fairways—often just “so we want that to be on the film,” underscoring the desire to document the course’s beauty as much as the play.

title: Closing Thanks from Louie & Nancy Ellis
summary: Near the end of the day, Louie’s voice closes with a heartfelt sign‑off thanking James D. and Jimmy Joe LaRosa for the opening day and saying it “will always be remembered by all,” adding thanks and “God bless you” from himself, Nancy, their families, and friends. It encapsulates the gratitude and community spirit of the archive.

title: Congressman Alan Mollohan Praises Jimmy LaRosa
summary: On camera at the lakeside event, Congressman Alan Mollohan speaks warmly about Jimmy LaRosa’s years of work and how meaningful the project has been to him. He says it feels good to see the vision coming to fruition and that Jimmy “deserves it,” while his son Andrew shyly answers questions about his golf and clinics.

title: On‑Course Interview with Congressman Alan Mollohan & Son
chapter: On‑Course Interview with Congressman Alan Mollohan & Son
summary: Later in the day, Louie or Harris interviews Congressman Alan Mollohan and his young son Andrew on camera. Mollohan praises Jimmy LaRosa’s long‑term commitment and says it’s nice to see the vision coming to fruition; he calls the landscape beautiful and predicts the course will be beautiful as well. Andrew, age 12, is asked his handicap and gives a non‑answer (“We’re still figuring it out”), prompting a joking aside about “that’s a politician for you.” Mollohan notes Andrew has taken junior clinics and looks forward to playing the course. This segment situates the club within a broader civic context and shows political support for the project.

title: Lakeside Opening Dinner – Dignitaries, Bagpipers & Crowd
chapter: Lakeside Opening Dinner – Dignitaries, Bagpipers & Crowd
summary: Evening footage shows a formal lakeside dinner in honor of the Pete Dye Golf Club opening. Long rows of white‑clothed tables and folded napkins are set; a large crowd of members, families, and dignitaries gathers near a pavilion. Harris Holt narrates that this is “the dinner in honor of the Pete Dye Golf Club opening up” and points out dignitaries, including Congressman Alan Mollohan. A Scottish pipe band from Pittsburgh—the Syria Highlanders—arrives in full tartan regalia. Members of the band introduce themselves on camera (Tom Murray, Stuart Ball, Charlie Gladich, Bob Gordy, Bill Pfeiffer, Bill Gordy) and note their national reputation and competition wins. The band then marches and plays around the first tee and lakeside banquet area as a formal speech (likely Jimmy LaRosa) is heard in voiceover, again recounting the 15‑year journey, Pete Dye’s absence and family retreat, and the role of “the great architect in the sky” and Mother Nature. Families with children, including a suited man holding a little girl in a floral dress, are repeatedly framed, emphasizing the multi‑generational nature of the celebration.

title: Children Learning Golf on the Tee
summary: A toddler with a tiny club is helped by an adult woman on a tee box while other adults look on and laugh. The scene plays under narration about each hole feeling private and the course being “your favorite place,” visually tying the design philosophy to family experiences and future generations of golfers.

title: Pipe Band Marches to the First Tee
summary: The Syria Highlanders pipe band, in full tartan regalia, marches past the “1 PAR 4” tee marker and around the lakeside banquet area as a speech about the 15‑year journey and Pete Dye’s absence plays in voiceover. The visual pageantry and solemn music give the opening a ceremonial, almost sacred feel.

title: Fireworks Over the Club – July 3, 1993
chapter: Fireworks Over the Club – July 3, 1993
summary: Nighttime footage (timestamps 10:26–10:56 PM, 7/3/93) shows an extended fireworks display over the property—large red and gold bursts, rising comets, and scattered star‑like patterns. Over parts of this, the same speech audio about the club’s history, Pete Dye’s regrets at not attending, and thanks to God and Mother Nature is heard, creating a symbolic overlay of celebration and reflection. The fireworks likely coincide with Independence Day weekend and the club’s opening festivities. The sequence then cuts indoors to a late‑night clubhouse party: balloons, people filming each other, and a warm, seated interview with an older white‑haired man in a white polo (likely Jimmy LaRosa or another senior leader) who reiterates the 15‑year story and future vision. The night ends with candid shots of a gray‑haired man holding a young girl with a white bow, underscoring the family dimension of the celebration.

title: Fireworks & Tribute to ‘The Great Architect in the Sky’
summary: During a nighttime fireworks display on July 3, 1993, the speaker’s voice is heard thanking “the man above,” the “great architect in the sky,” and Mother Nature, and relaying Pete Dye’s praise for the property. The combination of fireworks and spiritual language elevates the club’s story beyond business into something almost mythic.

title: On‑Course Interview with Older Leader in White Polo
summary: In a quiet indoor interview, an older white‑haired man in a white polo (likely Jimmy LaRosa or another senior leader) calmly recounts the 15‑year project and emphasizes focusing on the future. He then recognizes Pete Dye, God, and Mother Nature. The intimate framing contrasts with the earlier public ceremony, giving a reflective, personal capstone to the narrative.

title: Closing Family Moments & Production Credit
chapter: Closing Family Moments & Production Credit
summary: The final minutes intercut more fireworks bursts with intimate indoor family scenes. A gray‑haired man in glasses holds a young blonde girl with a white bow as they smile at the camera in a fluorescent‑lit clubhouse room. The same man appears again as the fireworks audio/narration continues, visually tying the club’s public story to private family joy. The reel ends with a close‑up of the Ellis Productions business card, crediting Louis P. Ellis as producer/director and listing his Clarksburg address and services (weddings, anniversaries, meetings, film‑to‑video transfers). This explicitly identifies the amateur production source of much of the archive and closes the loop on Louie’s long‑running documentation of the Pete Dye Golf Club story.

title: 1. Ellis Productions Title & Guest House Interior Tour Setup
chapter: 1. Ellis Productions Title & Guest House Interior Tour Setup
summary: The tape opens with an Ellis Productions title card and business card crediting “Louis P. Ellis, Producer/Director.” It then cuts to the new Pete Dye Golf Club guest house, where Valerie Smith is introduced as the Atlanta‑based interior designer with roots in Harrison County. Louie explains he will “scan” the room while Valerie describes it. She explains that the room is for individual guests with private exterior access, points out the cherry armoire from Friendly Furniture in Fairmont, the table for in‑room coffee and work, two queen beds, and golf‑themed prints loaned from a member’s private collection. The camera documents the beds, artwork, and a functional bathroom with double vanity, shower, and private water closet.

title: Valerie Smith’s Functional Guest Room Tour
summary: Valerie explains that the guest room is for individual guests with private exterior access, points out the cherry armoire from Friendly Furniture in Fairmont, the in‑room table for coffee and work, and two queen beds beneath member‑loaned golf prints.

title: 2. Guest House Bedrooms, Living Areas, and Member‑Contributed Décor
chapter: 2. Guest House Bedrooms, Living Areas, and Member‑Contributed Décor
summary: The tour continues through additional guest rooms and common areas. Valerie emphasizes that the bathrooms are “very functional” with plenty of mirrors and can comfortably accommodate two people. Louie notes there are eight beautiful bedrooms in the guest house and that the two Connecticut guests they just interviewed will be staying there. The camera shows more beds, bathrooms, a checkerboard inlaid into a table, and an outdoor deck on both floors. From the deck, Louie films the back nine under construction/completion and praises the view, calling it “awesome” and marveling at the coal from the real Columbia Mine and the line of coal cars used as a course feature. He repeatedly praises “Mr. LaRosa, Jimmy Joe and the crew… Pete Dye, what a beauty you have created here in the hills of West Virginia.”

title: 3. Lakes, Back Nine Landscape & Mining Heritage Features
chapter: 3. Lakes, Back Nine Landscape & Mining Heritage Features
summary: Louie documents one of the last man‑made lakes on the back nine, noting it is still filling and will be in play on October 1, 1994. He frames the course as a dream of the LaRosas that “Pete Dye came to the rescue” to realize. Scenic shots show ponds, fairways, wooded hills, and the line of coal cars that reference the site’s mining history. This B‑roll is intercut with or underlaid by Valerie’s continuing audio description of the guest house interiors, blending course scenery with hospitality details.

title: Louie’s Awe at the Back Nine & Coal Cars
summary: From the guest house deck, Louie films the back nine and the line of coal cars, calling the view “awesome,” praising Mr. LaRosa, Jimmy Joe, and Pete Dye for creating such beauty in the hills of West Virginia, and noting the real coal from the Columbia Mine.

title: 4. Tent Setup, Breakfast Buffet & Opening‑Day Staff Introductions
chapter: 4. Tent Setup, Breakfast Buffet & Opening‑Day Staff Introductions
summary: The date shifts to October 1, 1994. Early‑morning shots show large white tents, long banquet tables with white cloths, and a breakfast/refreshment setup near the course. Louie films the buffet line and jokes about hoping to get fed because he doesn’t get paid for video. He introduces several women working the opening: Julie Goodwin, Clarice Burkhammer, and Ann Hart. He teases one woman about hiding from the camera and captures candid smiles and nervousness. The atmosphere is anticipatory as staff finalize preparations for the back‑nine opening and member‑guest event.

title: 5. Harris, the Harts & Breakfast Line Comedy
chapter: 5. Harris, the Harts & Breakfast Line Comedy
summary: Louie continues around the breakfast area, introducing more staff. Carol Hart identifies herself and confirms Ann is her younger sister. Louie and Harris Holt joke about rearranging the jelly and butter correctly; Harris insists Louie “didn’t get this done correctly” so he and Ann had to fix it. Harris identifies himself on camera and directs Louie to “take a picture of this,” playing the bossy friend. Chef Chris is introduced at the grill. Louie repeatedly jokes about wanting proof that he got to eat and that the food is “on LaRose,” while Harris films him going through the line for a second helping. The segment ends with Louie filming a dramatic sunrise over the course, marveling at the rays and asking Harris to confirm how beautiful it is.

title: Harris & Ann ‘Fix’ the Jelly and Butter
summary: Harris Holt scolds Louie for not setting up the jelly and butter correctly and, with Ann Hart, rearranges the items while narrating what they’re doing. Louie laughs and calls it “always Harris telling me what to do.”

title: 6. Formal Lakefront Introduction & Sunrise Over the Course
chapter: 6. Formal Lakefront Introduction & Sunrise Over the Course
summary: An older man in a light suit with a camera around his neck stands by a misty lake and delivers a formal on‑camera introduction: this is the showing of the new guest house at the official opening of Pete Dye Golf Club, owned by James D. and Jimmy Joe LaRosa, designed by Pete Dye, on October 1, 1994, filmed by Louie Ellis. This is intercut with scenic shots of waterfalls, ponds, and long lines of golf carts and guests assembling near the clubhouse. Louie later films the sunrise and fog over the lake, comparing the mist to “The Hounds of the Baskervilles,” while Harris explains that all the carts are for members and their guests teeing off on grand opening day, likely playing all 18 holes including the new back nine.
characters: Unidentified suited host by lake (possibly Harris in different attire)

title: Sunrise Over Pete Dye Golf Club
summary: Louie films the sun rising over misty hills and the course, marveling at the rays and asking Harris if it isn’t beautiful. The timestamp and date are shown, anchoring the moment as the dawn of the official opening day.

title: 7. Guest House Guests & First Occupants: Mark Tinsher & Phil Asmundsen
chapter: 7. Guest House Guests & First Occupants: Mark Tinsher & Phil Asmundsen
summary: Inside or near the guest house, a club representative introduces two early arriving guests from Connecticut: Mark Tinsher (Stamford) and his guest Phil Asmundsen (Wilton). They got up at 5:30 to fly from New York. The host jokes that they don’t realize the honor—they are the first to stay in the guest house, and his own engagement was rescheduled to accommodate them for the second annual Men’s 1994 Member‑Guest and the inaugural opening of the back nine. There’s mention of a possible visit by Pete Dye depending on travel plans. Louie then shows the in‑room microwave, coffee pot, and stocked fridge for soft drinks, bottled water, snacks, and “a few beers,” joking about one guest being a part‑time preacher and not wanting to scare him. Louie notes there are eight bedrooms and that “when Jim does it, they do it right.”

title: First Guest House Occupants from Connecticut
summary: Mark Tinsher and Phil Asmundsen, who flew in early from New York, are told they are the first to stay in the guest house. The host jokes that his own engagement was rescheduled to accommodate them for the second annual Men’s Member‑Guest and the inaugural opening of the back nine.

title: 8. Member‑Guest Registration, Staff & Buffet Bar Details
chapter: 8. Member‑Guest Registration, Staff & Buffet Bar Details
summary: Louie roams between the guest house deck, buffet, and bar areas, filming staff and early guests. He captures Pam (greeted with “Buongiorno”), Ike Winter, and others. Harris Holt and Ann Hart again rearrange jelly and butter, ribbing Louie. Louie introduces Carol Hart and confirms her relation to Ann. Chef Chris is again shown. A suited man (likely Bill Stines) and Jimmy LaRosa appear at the registration area; Jimmy is described as “decked out like a page out of Esquire” and jokes that he “slept in the bunker last night.” Bill Stines identifies himself as “a friend of Jimmy LaRose’s just here to help out.” Louie plugs “video is provided by Ellis Productions, Route 50, east on Bridgeport Hill.” A bar table with liquor, wine, and glasses is filmed, as well as fruit bowls and décor, underscoring the club’s hospitality.

title: 9. Mass Player Roll‑Call: Member‑Guest Teams & Hometowns
chapter: 9. Mass Player Roll‑Call: Member‑Guest Teams & Hometowns
summary: A large portion of the tape is devoted to Louie standing on a tee or staging area and systematically filming every member‑guest pairing as they introduce themselves. Each duo gives names and hometowns: Mark Tinsher & Phil Asmundsen (CT), Parker Smith & Wally Uline, Jim Jackson & Bob DeMoss, Tim Dyer & Dave Hanna, Mickey Trevino & Jim Westfall, Marty Roach & Lou Guest, Glenn Adrian & Ken Jeskowicz, Alex Chang & Randy Resnick, Nick Johnson & Dave Watson, Ron Blankenship & Pat Weaver, Ed Heflin & Len Shirley, Paul Gabriel & George Petitti, Jerry Kendrick & Don C. (Albany, GA), Jeff Lawrenson & Dave Allman, Jack Muscaro & John Pignetti, and many more. Louie jokes about bank robberies when players mention Morgantown, teases about being “wanted in five states,” and notes that Louie Allman made a hole‑in‑one on number 7 with a 7‑iron and had to buy drinks for the house. The roll‑call continues with players from West Virginia, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Georgia, Illinois, Nebraska, Florida, Maryland, and beyond, illustrating the club’s reach and the scale of the event.

title: Mass Player Roll‑Call & Running Jokes
summary: Louie stands on a tee and records dozens of member‑guest pairs introducing themselves and their hometowns. He jokes about bank robberies, being “wanted in five states,” and Irish names, while also noting a hole‑in‑one and players’ long travels.

title: Kevin Dawson’s ‘Magician’ Bit
summary: Kevin Dawson from Atlanta, introduced as Louie’s guest, pretends to push golf balls through someone’s body, demonstrating his “magician” skills for the camera.

title: 10. More Teams, Running Gags & Magician Interlude
chapter: 10. More Teams, Running Gags & Magician Interlude
summary: The introductions continue with more teams: Bill Eggert & Fred Summers (who boast they will “definitely win this event”), Bob Mays & Vince Simonetti, Don Gracie & Bob Quinn, C.E. White & Scott Runyon, Paul Cox & Ben Amon, Richard Cicchetti & Pete Gabriel, Tom Douglas & Roger Lohosick, Jeff Smith & Dan Pickens (joking about not being the wealthy Dr. Pickens), Frank Mazey & Rodney LaRose (Rodney defends his partner as “a great man”), Dr. John Tucker & Mark Fentye, Hugh Staley & Dan Bonar, Manny Alvarez & Brian Mosser, Jeff Keester & David Alvarez, Dale Ramsburg & Brian Amon, and many more. Kevin Dawson from Atlanta, Louie’s guest, performs a quick “magician” bit, pretending to push golf balls through someone. Louie keeps up a patter of jokes about Irish names, political campaigns (Jimmy Kan running for House of Delegates), and players’ hometowns, while also noting special feats like Louie Allman’s hole‑in‑one.

title: 11. Afternoon Foursomes & On‑Course Portraits
chapter: 11. Afternoon Foursomes & On‑Course Portraits
summary: Later in the day, Louie continues filming pairs and small groups on various tees and greens, now with timestamps around late morning and early afternoon. Players pose with clubs, sometimes in themed sweaters or bright outfits, and often joke or banter with Louie. Some are filmed mid‑swing or putting. The audio from Valerie’s guest‑house tour is sometimes overlaid on these visuals, indicating later editing or dubbing. The sequence shows the course in full use, with carts, fall foliage, and the new back nine in play, reinforcing the sense of a vibrant, well‑attended opening‑day tournament.
characters: Numerous unnamed or previously named golfers

title: 12. Closing: James D. LaRosa’s On‑Camera Blessing & Thanks to Nancy
chapter: 12. Closing: James D. LaRosa’s On‑Camera Blessing & Thanks to Nancy
summary: Near the end, Louie announces, “We keep the best for last,” and turns the camera on James D. LaRosa. James jokingly calls himself “the chaplain” and says that every time he goes around there are three signs saying “Praise the Lord.” He identifies himself as “James D., Jimmy Joe’s dad,” and says he’s having a big, special day and is proud of the whole organization. Louie prompts him to say something to Nancy Ellis; James greets “Mrs. Nance” and thanks Nancy for her support and for making things more available to them. Louie then cuts back to the back nine, declaring, “There we are folks, on the back nine, the first official day opening of the Pete Dye Golf Club. Isn’t that beautiful?” The tape ends with wind noise and repeated comments about “a lot of wind,” underscoring the raw, documentary nature of the footage.

title: James D. LaRosa’s Closing Blessing
summary: James D. LaRosa calls himself “the chaplain,” identifies as “James D., Jimmy Joe’s dad,” and expresses pride in the big, special day. He greets Nancy Ellis and thanks her for her support, providing an emotional capstone to the opening‑day footage.

title: Declaration of the Back Nine’s First Official Day
summary: Louie films the back nine and declares, “There we are folks, on the back nine, the first official day opening of the Pete Dye Golf Club. Isn’t that beautiful?” emphasizing the historic nature of the moment.

title: Opening Ceremony, Invocation, and ‘Healthy West Virginia’ Toast
chapter: Opening Ceremony, Invocation, and ‘Healthy West Virginia’ Toast
summary: The video opens on the 1995 Harrison County Chamber of Commerce annual dinner in a hotel/banquet hall. A color guard presents the colors, and Father King from All Saints Catholic Church in Bridgeport delivers an invocation blessing the community and those to be honored. The master of ceremonies (Executive Director Walter Barnes) then shifts to a humorous health‑themed segment, asking how many attendees can find skim or 1% milk in local stores and introducing a recurring ‘Healthy West Virginia’ toast. He and ‘Walter’ (or ‘Walt’) pledge to drink skim milk instead of wine to ‘save us both from cholesterol,’ joking that the program has been so successful they now ‘wear copper 50s.’ This sets a light, convivial tone while nodding to statewide health initiatives.

title: ‘Healthy West Virginia’ Skim‑Milk Toast
summary: The emcee asks how many attendees can find skim or 1% milk in local stores, jokes that managers can’t keep it in stock, and introduces a ‘Healthy West Virginia’ toast. While others drink wine, he and ‘Walt’ pledge to drink skim milk to avoid cholesterol, joking that the program has been so successful they now ‘wear copper 50s.’

title: Chamber Business, Introductions, and Board/Staff Recognition
chapter: Chamber Business, Introductions, and Board/Staff Recognition
summary: The emcee and Chamber leadership formally recognize the head table, including President Gary Bowden, past president Dr. Murray, vice presidents Anthony Mancuso and Bob Kaplan, and other officers. Board members are asked to stand, identified by flowers on their lapels. Chamber staff Mary Beth (office manager) and Madeline Phillips (‘resident consultant’ and ‘First Lady of the Chamber’) are introduced and praised for their work. A representative from the Marion County Chamber (Charlie Reese) and political figures such as the mayor of Shinnston (Wanda Ashcraft), gubernatorial candidate David McKinley, and a representative from Congressman Alan Mollohan’s office are acknowledged. The emcee stresses the importance of small business membership and committee involvement, and thanks volunteers who organized the event.

title: Keynote Focus: Honoring Health‑Care Providers and Introducing Dr. Jacobson
chapter: Keynote Focus: Honoring Health‑Care Providers and Introducing Dr. Jacobson
summary: The Chamber dedicates this year’s recognition theme to health‑care providers in Harrison County. Attendees associated with hospitals, clinics, and medical facilities are asked to stand and be thanked. Bruce Carter, President and CEO of United Hospital Center, speaks on behalf of the two local hospitals, emphasizing that the most important group to recognize are the frontline staff working three shifts a day, especially during blizzards when many stayed at the hospital for days. He then introduces Dr. Charles Jacobson, a physician and former President/CEO of Park Nicollet Medical Center in Minneapolis, now with SunHealth. Carter frames Minneapolis as the ‘laboratory’ of managed care and notes Jacobson’s West Virginia ties through training at WVU. Dr. Jacobson is invited to give a keynote on health‑care reform and managed care.

title: Dr. Jacobson’s Health‑Care Reform Keynote (Slides: History, Problems, and Minnesota Model)
chapter: Dr. Jacobson’s Health‑Care Reform Keynote (Slides: History, Problems, and Minnesota Model)
summary: Dr. Charles Jacobson delivers a detailed, slide‑supported talk on U.S. health care. He begins by acknowledging the complexity of the topic and joking about the political debate around health care and the Clintons. He stresses that health care has done ‘absolutely profoundly wonderful things’ for society but is now in crisis due to costs and access. Slides trace four historical drivers: individual freedom, a large country of small towns, employer‑based health insurance, and the creation of the National Institutes of Health. He explains how solo small‑town doctors were paid in kind, how employers in the 1940s used health insurance to retain workers, and how post‑WWII science (atomic bomb, air travel) led to NIH and explosive medical advances (pacemakers, bypass surgery, MRI, CAT scans, mammograms, transplants, artificial joints, cancer cures, modern hypertension and lipid drugs). Subsequent slides labeled ‘1995 Problems’ outline issues: science driving costs, doctors overwhelmed by knowledge and working in disconnected ‘cottage industry’ practices without integrated records, and insurance companies controlling costs despite limited clinical knowledge. Jacobson uses a ‘1953 Corvette’ analogy to illustrate the dysfunction of buying complex systems piecemeal with a third party paying the bills. He contrasts externally controlled systems (like national HMOs) with community‑built, internally controlled systems, arguing that communities should create integrated health‑care systems to keep control and profits local. He presents Minnesota’s experience: merging Park Nicollet and Group Health, integrating hospitals, reducing redundant technology (CTs, surgery centers, cancer centers), standardizing best practices among 3,000 physicians (including Mayo Clinic), and achieving 20% lower costs with high quality (e.g., low cardiovascular mortality). He concludes that American health care, if allowed to experiment, can become the envy of the world and a major export, and urges local business leaders to help build integrated, patient‑focused systems rather than cede control to distant corporations.

title: Dr. Jacobson’s Minnesota Health Care Case Study
summary: Dr. Charles Jacobson explains how Minnesota’s major employers pushed for change, leading Park Nicollet and Group Health to merge with hospitals and health plans to create an integrated system. He describes eliminating redundant CT scanners and surgery centers, standardizing best practices among 3,000 physicians (including Mayo Clinic), and achieving 20% lower costs with high quality outcomes.

title: Optimism, Telemedicine, and Call to Local Action
chapter: Optimism, Telemedicine, and Call to Local Action
summary: In the latter part of his talk, Dr. Jacobson discusses the need for integrated systems, robust information technology, and a shift from disease treatment to health promotion. He notes that technology that ‘bites us’ on cost can also help if used properly (e.g., ambulatory information systems, guidelines at the point of care, medical records in patients’ homes). He describes Minnesota’s reductions in hospital beds and costs without sacrificing quality, and mentions Park Nicollet’s low cardiovascular mortality. He outlines ‘future drivers’ of U.S. health care: individual rights, health vs. disease treatment, care systems vs. insurance systems, and human values vs. pure science. He expresses strong optimism that American medicine will innovate its way to being the envy of the world, with private enterprise exporting health‑care expertise. He references telemedicine and teleradiology as examples of emerging opportunities. Jacobson closes by stressing that ‘it is your health care system, it is your community,’ urging local businesspeople and citizens to create their own integrated systems rather than be controlled by distant entities like New York or L.A. The audience applauds, and the Chamber presents him with a ‘low‑cost health‑care package’ of West Virginia food products as a humorous thank‑you gift to take back to Carolina.

title: Citizen of the Year: Honoring James D. LaRosa
chapter: Citizen of the Year: Honoring James D. LaRosa
summary: After the keynote, the program moves into the recognition portion. Chamber President Gary Bowden (or another officer) invites the president, Gary Godwin/Bowden, to present the 1995 Harrison County Chamber of Commerce Citizen of the Year. The presenter reads an extensive citation describing the honoree: a loyal West Virginian, devoted Harrison Countian, and committed Clarksburger; graduate of Washington Irving High School and West Virginia University; successful coal businessman; former director of the Chamber, Lowndes Bank, and the WV Surface Mining and Reclamation Association; appointee to the WV Coal Commission; founder and former chairman of the WV Italian Heritage Festival. The honoree donated and built the WVU Hospital Medivac helipad and established a surgical research endowment. Numerous institutions—Harrison County YMCA, Wheeling College, United Hospital Center, Clarksburg Library, Humane Society, youth sports leagues, Upshur County schools, Buckhannon Fire Department, Fraternal Order of Police, and the Statue of Liberty restoration fund—are listed as beneficiaries of his generosity. Awards include a Doctor of Humane Letters from Salem College, nomination by Senator Byrd to the Presidential Christopher Columbus Quincentennial Jubilee Commission, Distinguished West Virginian honors from Governors Moore and Rockefeller, a Distinguished Service Award from the Clarksburg Arts Center, and an American Legion citation for support of baseball. The presenter then reveals that the Citizen of the Year is James D. LaRosa, noting that he built and developed East Point Shopping Center, recently finished the Pete Dye Championship Golf Course in Bridgeport, owns the Rose Garden Theater, and sold land for the WV Life Sciences Center and the future Robert C. Byrd High School. The audience gives a standing ovation. LaRosa comes to the podium, jokes that he won’t touch the microphone, and gives a brief, humble speech: he has lived all his life within a couple of miles of his high school and considers himself a ‘native son’; he thanks the Chamber and hopes he has helped the quality of life for all; he credits his parents’ love, support, and teaching for his success. The presenter calls the award ‘well deserved, long overdue.’

title: Citizen of the Year Award to James D. LaRosa
summary: The Chamber presents its 1995 Citizen of the Year award to James D. LaRosa, citing his extensive civic, charitable, and business contributions, including building East Point Shopping Center, finishing the Pete Dye Championship Golf Course in Bridgeport, and supporting hospitals, schools, and cultural institutions. LaRosa gives a brief, heartfelt acceptance speech, calling himself a ‘native son’ and crediting his parents.

title: Executive Director’s Outstanding Small Business of the Year: Oliverio’s Italian Style Peppers
chapter: Executive Director’s Outstanding Small Business of the Year: Oliverio’s Italian Style Peppers
summary: Executive Director Walter Barnes introduces the next award: the Executive Director’s Outstanding Small Business of the Year. He explains his background in big business and his realization, through Chamber work, that ‘in West Virginia, small business is big business,’ noting that about 70% of Chamber membership is small businesses (75 or fewer employees). He cites mission‑statement words—growth, stability, commitment, recognition of product/services, and community association—as criteria. He then describes the winning business without naming it at first: started in a small Glen Elk kitchen by a woman preparing peppers for her corner grocery; production grew from 65 bushels in two weeks to over 600 bushels in one day; expanded from the grocery kitchen to a large modern facility on Stiles Street (‘the Pepper Plant’) and a new administrative building on Ohio Avenue; workforce grew to 35–40 employees, more during peak canning; three generations of family involvement; major commitment to expansion announced the previous summer; products now on shelves across West Virginia and up and down the Atlantic seaboard, shipping to every state in the continental U.S. He then reveals the honoree: Oliverio’s Italian Style Peppers. Quoting Frank Oliverio about wanting to always do a job they can be proud of, Barnes praises the family and calls them an outstanding promotion for Harrison County. Frank and Mark Oliverio come up to accept; they modestly say neither is a speaker and simply thank the Chamber before returning to their seats. Barnes jokes that Frank hopes he doesn’t have to go back and cut peppers and ‘cut his finger off the way you said that.’

title: Executive Director’s Small Business of the Year: Oliverio’s Italian Style Peppers
summary: Executive Director Walter Barnes tells the story of a family pepper business that grew from a Glen Elk kitchen to a modern plant and national distribution, then reveals Oliverio’s Italian Style Peppers as the 1995 Outstanding Small Business of the Year. Frank and Mark Oliverio accept the award modestly, thanking the Chamber and returning quickly to their seats.

title: Ambassador of the Year and Closing Remarks
chapter: Ambassador of the Year and Closing Remarks
summary: The final award is the Ambassador of the Year, normally presented by LaDonna Fox, chair of the Ambassadors Committee, but she is absent, so Walter Barnes reads hastily prepared remarks. He explains that the award goes to the person who best exemplifies the Chamber’s role in the community—visible at most Chamber functions (open houses, ribbon cuttings, business after hours, dedications, groundbreakings, and any event drawing two or more people). The recipient must be dedicated, willing to give time and effort to represent the Chamber. This year’s honoree is a retired gentleman who travels a lot but still makes special efforts to attend events. Barnes jokes that when people saw him and another man (Brett) in purple jackets, they might think they got a deal at Gabriel’s, but the jackets signify their role as Chamber ambassadors. He announces the Ambassador of the Year for 1995 as Mr. John Lowe (or Love), who comes forward wearing the same purple jacket. After this, Barnes notes that the program is at its end, thanks Walt Williams, Frank Abruzzini, and office staff for organizing the event, and encourages members to get involved in Chamber committees listed on the back of the program. He invites people to stop by the Chamber office at 348 West Main Street, promising coffee, candy from Mary Beth, or a smile from Madeline. He emphasizes that without members’ support and involvement, the Chamber is nothing, and closes with wishes for a safe trip home and ‘we’ll see you next year.’ The tape ends with an Ellis Productions title card crediting Louis P. Ellis as producer/director, confirming that Louie and Nancy Ellis documented the event.

title: Ambassador of the Year: John Lowe
summary: In the absence of the Ambassadors Committee chair, Walter Barnes improvises remarks to present the Ambassador of the Year award. He describes the honoree as a retired gentleman who travels extensively yet still makes time to represent the Chamber at countless events, and jokes about their purple ambassador jackets. He announces Mr. John Lowe as the 1995 Ambassador of the Year.

title: Nationwide Tour action at Pete Dye Golf Club – Par‑3s and D.A. Points’ surge
chapter: Nationwide Tour action at Pete Dye Golf Club – Par‑3s and D.A. Points’ surge
summary: The broadcast opens in mid‑round coverage of the Nationwide Tour’s Pete Dye West Virginia Classic at Pete Dye Golf Club. Announcers focus on the difficulty of the par‑3s, especially the elevated 7th and 16th, noting all four par‑3s are playing over par. D.A. Points is highlighted as co‑leader and then solo leader, hitting every fairway and green, making multiple birdies in a row, and turning in 30 on the front nine to reach −13. Other players like Gavin Coles, Charles Warren, Doug LaBelle, Ryan Hietala, and Darron Stiles are shown hitting approaches, bunker shots, and putts on holes 7, 8, 9, 16, and 18. The mine portal between 6 and 7 is featured visually, with commentary about the site’s coal‑mining history and Pete Dye’s insistence on preserving mining artifacts. Commercials for Porsche, Medicus, and various consumer products are interspersed, but the core narrative is live tournament play and course description.

title: Mine portal feature – from coal to golf
summary: Cameras travel through the dark No. 6 mine portal between the 6th and 7th holes, showing timbered tunnels and dim lights. Announcers explain that the LaRosa family initially wanted to cover up mining remnants, but Pete Dye insisted on keeping coal globs, mine cars, and portals as what makes the course special. They discuss responsible reclamation laws and call the course a hidden treasure and one of the best examples of reclaimed mining land in West Virginia.

title: D.A. Points’ four straight birdies and front‑nine 30
summary: A highlight package shows D.A. Points birdieing the 2nd, 3rd, 5th, 6th, 7th, and 8th holes. He stuffs wedges close, controls distance perfectly on elevated par‑3s, and rolls in every makeable putt. He turns in 30 and reaches −13, with 26 bogey‑free holes.

title: Nationwide Tour graduates’ success on the PGA Tour
summary: A produced segment highlights Zach Johnson’s two Nationwide wins, Player of the Year honors, and subsequent PGA Tour victory at the BellSouth Classic, along with over $1.5M in earnings. Graphics show other 2003 Nationwide grads like Mark Hensby, Bo Van Pelt, and others surpassing $1M on the PGA Tour. The announcers draw parallels between Zach’s John Deere Classic experience and D.A. Points’ recent PGA Tour start, suggesting Points also “belongs” on the big tour.

title: Commercial block and Golf Channel promos (Medicus, NMA, Open Championship Week)
chapter: Commercial block and Golf Channel promos (Medicus, NMA, Open Championship Week)
summary: A long commercial and promo block interrupts live play. Ads include AJ Reveals the Truth About Golf, Gateway computers, American Century Championship, Golf Channel Video Vault, National Mining Association reclamation spots, BP cleaner fuels, Pioneer Investments, and various consumer products. Golf Channel promos for Open Championship Week at Royal Troon and Golf Central updates appear, with studio shots and leaderboards for the Open Championship and BC Open. These segments show how the Pete Dye event was packaged within broader Golf Channel programming and sponsor messaging, but contain no original on‑site club footage beyond scenic course shots used as ad backgrounds.

title: Return to live coverage – D.A. Points’ bogey‑free streak and course as reclaimed mine
chapter: Return to live coverage – D.A. Points’ bogey‑free streak and course as reclaimed mine
summary: Coverage returns to Pete Dye Golf Club. D.A. Points continues his bogey‑free run to 26 holes at −13, with Jerry Foltz describing a delicate bunker shot on 9 and the soft, recently replaced sand. Announcers praise his new, shorter backswing and improved accuracy, breaking down his swing in slow motion. Darron Stiles climbs to −9 with solid iron play and putting, while Nick Cassini, Jason Caron, Bobby Kalinowski, and others hover around the cut line. A feature segment explicitly frames the course as a reclaimed strip mine and coal site, with the mine portal, coal cars, and the “Pittsburgh Seam” referenced. The LaRosa family’s initial desire to cover mining remnants is contrasted with Pete Dye’s insistence on leaving them as defining features. The term “responsible reclamation” is used, and the National Mining Association is mentioned as a sponsor. The course is called a “hidden treasure” and “18 of [Pete Dye’s] most memorable holes.”

title: Charles Warren’s disaster at 18
summary: Charles Warren, having played four birdies and one bogey, faces a treacherous downhill third shot at 18. His ball rolls too far, then his fourth shot from a tricky lie also runs down a hump, leaving a difficult bogey putt. He misses and takes a double bogey, dropping to −4 for the tournament. Announcers stress the importance of at least saving bogey when making the turn.

title: Studio updates, Nationwide Tour graduate profiles, and external leaderboards
chapter: Studio updates, Nationwide Tour graduate profiles, and external leaderboards
summary: The broadcast periodically cuts to Golf Central updates from Orlando, where Mike Ritz reports on the Open Championship at Royal Troon (Skip Kendall leading, Levet, Singh, Els, Montgomerie) and the BC Open (John Morgan, Daniel Chopra, Kevin Stadler). Produced vignettes highlight Nationwide Tour graduates like Zach Johnson, Bo Van Pelt, and others who have surpassed $1M on the PGA Tour. Leaderboards for the Open and BC Open appear, as do graphics showing Nationwide Tour grads’ PGA Tour money lists. These segments contextualize the Pete Dye West Virginia Classic within the broader professional golf ecosystem and underscore the Nationwide Tour’s role as a pipeline to the PGA Tour. Meanwhile, the Pete Dye leaderboard is updated frequently, showing D.A. Points at −13, Bryce Molder at −11, and a deep field around the −1/−2 cut line.

title: Deep dive into Pete Dye Golf Club – mining heritage, design praise, and future ambitions
chapter: Deep dive into Pete Dye Golf Club – mining heritage, design praise, and future ambitions
summary: Announcers deliver a more reflective segment on Pete Dye Golf Club itself. They describe the property’s evolution from an Indian campground to a strip mine and now to a “masterpiece of a golf course.” The mine portal between 6 and 7 is shown, along with coal cars and the “Pittsburgh Seam” of coal. They note that Pete Dye insisted on keeping mining remnants visible, calling the course 18 of his most memorable holes. Pete Dye is said to have been on site earlier in the week for the pro‑am, and the commentators speculate about the course’s future, suggesting that if it hosts other events beyond the Nationwide Tour, the setup would be much firmer and faster (rain has made conditions soft this week). They discuss responsible reclamation laws in West Virginia and praise the LaRosa family’s vision and the course as one of the best examples of reclaimed mining land. Throughout, D.A. Points’ performance remains central, with questions about whether he will “run away and hide” given his 30 on the front nine and −13 total.

title: Bobby Kalinowski’s clutch birdie at 15
summary: Hovering around the cut line at −1, Bobby Kalinowski hits a lay‑up close to the hazard on the par‑5 15th, then plays a precise third shot and converts the birdie putt to move to −2. Announcers note that he and his brother Tom are one of the brother combinations on tour and that this birdie helps him get inside the cut.

title: Analysts praise Pete Dye Golf Club as a masterpiece
summary: During a reflective segment, the booth calls Pete Dye Golf Club “a masterpiece of a golf course” and quotes Pete Dye as saying it’s 18 of his most memorable holes. They recount that the property was once an Indian campground and strip mine, and now hosts a top‑tier course with big dreams and plans for future events. They note that rain softened conditions this week, but in future they’d want a firm, fast setup.

title: Closing stretch of second round and broadcast sign‑off
chapter: Closing stretch of second round and broadcast sign‑off
summary: The final portion of the broadcast window shows late‑afternoon play as players try to make the cut at −1/−2 and chase D.A. Points. Johnson Wagner, Nick Cassini, Jason Caron, Dave Stockton Jr., Bobby Kalinowski, and others hit approaches and putts on holes 14–18. Charles Warren’s double bogey at 18 is shown in detail, including his difficult third and fourth shots and the importance of holing a bogey putt to avoid a double. Darron Stiles remains at −9, four back of Points, with commentators praising his hunger to return to the PGA Tour. The cut line hovers at −1, with many players still on the course. Brian Anderson closes the show by promoting next day’s third‑round coverage at a new time (5 p.m. Eastern) and asking, “How low can D.A. Points go?” before signing off for the day.

title: Telecast Opening & Course Introduction
chapter: Telecast Opening & Course Introduction
summary: The Golf Channel opens its coverage of the inaugural Pete Dye West Virginia Classic, introducing Pete Dye Golf Club as a par‑72, 7,200‑yard “mountain retreat” and “hidden treasure” now on the Nationwide Tour schedule. Brian Anderson and Kurt Byram in the booth describe the course as visually spectacular and intimidating, note that it’s the only course bearing Pete Dye’s name, and highlight the reclaimed coal‑mine setting. They introduce key storylines: D.A. Points’ surprising 65, Nick Cassini’s 66, Darron Stiles’ 66, and Australian Paul Gow’s three playoff losses without a win. Early highlight packages show birdies and strong play from Greg Bruckner, Tom Scherrer, Troy Matteson, D.A. Points, Nick Cassini, and Mario Tiziani, while a conditions graphic notes soft greens, light wind, and 70°F temperatures.

title: D.A. Points’ 65 Sets the Pace
summary: D.A. Points fires a 7‑under 65 in soft, calm morning conditions, surprising commentators who expected Pete Dye Golf Club to play tougher. His round includes multiple birdies and no major mistakes, establishing the target score for the field.

title: Greg Bruckner’s Four Straight Birdies and 30 on the Front
summary: Greg Bruckner strings together four consecutive birdies, then hits his second shot at 18 to within a foot and converts to turn in 30 with six birdies and no bogeys. The booth highlights his aggressive drive down the left near the hazard and precise approach.

title: Front‑Nine Highlights & Early Scoring
chapter: Front‑Nine Highlights & Early Scoring
summary: On‑course reporters Jerry Foltz and Val Skinner join, following groups that include Ryuji Imada, Paul Gow, Scott Gump, Hunter Haas, Franklin Langham, Scott Gutschewski, and others. Highlights show Imada’s precise irons, Gow’s aggressive but erratic play, and Gump’s conservative fairway‑wood strategy. Mario Tiziani birdies the tough par‑3 16th; Bryce Molder continues his hot streak with birdies at 14–16; D.J. Trahan and Ty Tryon are shown taking advantage of drivable par‑4s and reachable par‑5s. The booth notes that soft greens and minimal wind are allowing lower scores than expected, with 40–60 players under par. Leaderboards are repeatedly shown, with D.A. Points at -7, Cassini and Stiles at -6, and a large pack at -3 to -4.

title: Mario Tiziani’s Birdie at the Brutal 16th
summary: Mario Tiziani, a Monday qualifier and Steve Stricker’s brother‑in‑law, hits a strong tee shot on the 209‑yard par‑3 16th and holes the uphill birdie putt, briefly reaching -5 before a bogey‑bogey finish. The booth notes the hole can be stretched to 240+ yards and praises his 20 putts through 16 holes.

title: Scott Gutschewski’s Power and Touch
summary: Described as a “corn‑fed Nebraskan” with a 305‑yard average, Gutschewski unleashes long drives on par‑5s, then shows finesse with wedges and putts. He reaches the par‑5 8th in two, nearly makes eagle, and converts back‑to‑back birdies at 8 and 9 to reach -2 at the turn.

title: Course Architecture, Coal‑Mine Heritage & LaRosa–Dye Story
chapter: Course Architecture, Coal‑Mine Heritage & LaRosa–Dye Story
summary: Between live shots and highlights, the booth delves into the course’s 15‑year construction on a reclaimed coal mine. Byram explains that the LaRosa family assembled the land in 1979 and gave Pete Dye unusual creative freedom, resulting in what Dye considers his favorite project. They describe how the owners initially wanted to erase coal‑mining remnants, but Dye insisted on keeping coal gobs, tipples, and shafts, saying he wouldn’t return if they were removed. Camera shots linger on the coal tipple, mine shafts, tunnels, and strip‑mine scars integrated into holes like the par‑3 7th and the dramatic 18th. The commentators emphasize that the LaRosas were in no hurry, wanting every hole to be special, and that the club now has about 500 members from 27 states and five countries, functioning as a national retreat.

title: Bryce Molder’s Run of Four Straight Top‑10s
summary: Bryce Molder, who started the year with no status, is highlighted for playing his way onto the tour via Monday qualifiers and sponsor exemptions. He continues his hot streak with birdies at 14, 15, and 16, showing confident wedge play and putting.

title: Pete Dye’s Coal‑Mine Aesthetic Preserved
summary: The broadcast shows coal tipples, shafts, strip‑mine scars, and a tunnel between the 6th and 7th holes while Byram explains that the LaRosa family wanted to erase the mining remnants, but Pete Dye insisted they be kept, saying he wouldn’t come back otherwise. The result is praised as unique, picturesque, and visually stimulating.

title: Mid‑Round Live Coverage: Key Groups & Scoring Moves
chapter: Mid‑Round Live Coverage: Key Groups & Scoring Moves
summary: Live coverage focuses on several feature groups. The Imada–Gow–Gump group is followed closely: Imada hits strong irons but struggles with putts; Gow scrambles for pars with creative recoveries; Gump plays steady, conservative golf. Hunter Haas navigates the picturesque par‑3 7th (reached via a coal‑mine tunnel) and the reachable par‑5 8th, where he lags a long eagle putt. Franklin Langham battles early bogeys but shows touch with pitches and putts at 3, 5, 8, and 9. Scott Gutschewski, the “big man from Omaha,” uses his length to reach par‑5s in two and makes back‑to‑back birdies to reach -2. Bryce Molder continues his run of four straight top‑10s with birdies at 14, 15, and 16. The booth repeatedly notes that all four par‑3s are playing over par and will be difficult every day.

title: Golf Central Updates: Open Championship & B.C. Open
chapter: Golf Central Updates: Open Championship & B.C. Open
summary: Several cutaways to Golf Central in Orlando, hosted by Mike Ritz, provide updates from the 133rd Open Championship at Royal Troon and the PGA Tour’s B.C. Open. Ritz reports Paul Casey and Thomas Levet leading at -5, with Michael Campbell, K.J. Choi, Vijay Singh, Ernie Els, Retief Goosen, John Daly, Tiger Woods, Phil Mickelson, and others at various scores. He also announces the death of former PGA Tour player Jeff Julian from ALS and recalls his courage in playing Q‑School and Tour events after diagnosis. Another graphic shows Nationwide Tour graduates (Jason Bohn, Tom Carter, Lucas Glover, Tommy Tolles, Craig Bowden, Jason Dufner, Ted Purdy, Vaughn Taylor, Blaine McCallister, Tripp Isenhour, Guy Boros) performing well at the B.C. Open, reinforcing the Nationwide Tour as a pipeline to the PGA Tour.

title: Player Profiles, Trivia & Alumni Stories
chapter: Player Profiles, Trivia & Alumni Stories
summary: The telecast includes lighter feature content and alumni profiles. Jerry Foltz hosts a “Teed Up” trivia segment with Todd Demsey, asking pop‑culture and golf questions (Eddie Murphy’s character in Trading Places, first internationally famous board game, capital of West Virginia, Masters champion who was 1998 Q‑School medalist, etc.), scoring answers as birdies or bogeys. A profile graphic highlights John Daly’s path from Nationwide Tour (9th on money list) to winning the 1991 PGA and 1995 Open. The booth also discusses other Nationwide alumni like Mark Hensby, who just won on the PGA Tour, and notes his controversial decision to skip the Open Championship. Throughout, they emphasize that many current PGA Tour winners and major champions came through this tour, reinforcing the tagline “where the future is playing now.”

title: Late‑Afternoon Conditions & Course Philosophy
chapter: Late‑Afternoon Conditions & Course Philosophy
summary: As the afternoon wave progresses, Anderson and Byram discuss how soft greens and light winds have made the course more scoreable than locals expected, but note that when it firms up, Pete Dye’s undulating greens will be far more punishing. They explain that the LaRosas gave Dye nearly 15 years and full creative freedom, unusual in golf architecture, and that Dye refused to accept some suggested changes. They describe the 18th as a dramatic finishing par‑4 where players can’t see the green from the fairway, adding psychological difficulty. They also highlight the par‑3 13th with a severe ridge and the par‑3 4th as one of the toughest holes, where three is a good score. Leaderboards show D.A. Points at -7, Cassini and Stiles at -6, and a large pack at -3 to -4, with about 60 players under par. The course’s reclaimed‑mine visuals (coal tipple, shafts, strip‑mine scars) are repeatedly shown and praised as “unique, picturesque, and visually stimulating.”

title: Ongoing Live Coverage & Scoring Stories
chapter: Ongoing Live Coverage & Scoring Stories
summary: Live coverage continues to follow key players through the middle and late holes. Hunter Haas navigates bunker‑to‑bunker trouble at 9 but nearly pulls off a “double sandy.” Franklin Langham uses his putting strength from the fringe to save par and later makes his first birdie at 8 to offset earlier bogeys. Scott Gutschewski converts back‑to‑back birdies to reach -2 at the turn. Ryuji Imada hits strong second shots into par‑5s but struggles to convert eagle and birdie putts, missing several to the right despite working on a straight‑back, straight‑through stroke with a putting track. Paul Gow continues a roller‑coaster round, hitting excellent wedges (e.g., 103 yards at 8) but also finding deep rough and bunkers, “inventing new ugly ways to make par.” Bryce Molder, Hunter Haas, Ty Tryon, and others are shown taking advantage of reachable par‑5s and drivable par‑4s, while the booth notes that afternoon wind is picking up and making scoring slightly tougher than in the morning.

title: Ryuji Imada’s Aggressive Second at the 8th
summary: From 219 yards on the par‑5 8th, Imada takes an aggressive line with his second shot despite ball‑above‑feet lie and severe right‑to‑left fairway slope. He holds the green in a low spot about 15 feet left of the hole, setting up an eagle chance and showcasing his iron prowess.

title: Hunter Haas’ Long Eagle Try at the 8th
summary: From “another zip code” at about 60 feet, Hunter Haas lags an eagle putt on the par‑5 8th that breaks multiple ways. He leaves it just short but secures an easy birdie, prompting praise for his lag putting and body language that shows both frustration and satisfaction.

title: Franklin Langham’s Fringe Putting Saves
summary: Langham, described as strong with the putter, repeatedly chooses to putt from the fringe rather than chip, including a key up‑and‑down at 9. Val Skinner notes that putting from the short fringe is often the smarter play, and Langham’s touch finally shows after a rusty stretch.

title: Golf Central Update & Wrap‑Around Context
chapter: Golf Central Update & Wrap‑Around Context
summary: Another Golf Central update from Mike Ritz revisits the Open Championship leaderboard, noting that a third player (Alastair Forsyth) has joined Casey and Levet at -5, with Vijay Singh at -3 and big names like Tiger Woods, Davis Love III, and Phil Mickelson at or around par. Ritz recounts Darren Clarke’s double bogey at 18 after going out of bounds. Back at Pete Dye, the booth continues to emphasize the course’s long gestation (land assembled in 1979, course finished in 1994) and the LaRosas’ patience in letting Dye “do exactly what he wanted with every hole.” They reiterate that Dye considered this his favorite project, partly because of that creative freedom. Live shots show Jimmy Walker flirting with Simpson Creek at 18, Hunter Haas nearly holing a bunker shot at 9, and Franklin Langham choosing to putt from the fringe rather than risk a wedge, demonstrating his putting strength. The segment ends with a comprehensive leaderboard rundown, showing players from -7 down through +5 and reinforcing how many Nationwide Tour alumni are now succeeding on the PGA Tour and in majors.

title: Scott Gutschewski’s Back‑to‑Back Birdies to -2
summary: After a solid front nine of mostly pars, Gutschewski makes his first birdie at 8, then hits a wedge to about two feet at the 9th and converts for back‑to‑back birdies, reaching -2. The booth notes he has “plugged along” hitting many good shots and that the birdies finally start to fall.

title: Commercial Block & Return to Nationwide Tour Coverage
chapter: Commercial Block & Return to Nationwide Tour Coverage
summary: The video opens in the middle of a Golf Channel commercial block: ads for golfdiscount.com (Adams GT 363 drivers and Tight Lies fairway woods), Fidelity Active Trader Services, and Dave Pelz’s putting DVD play over generic golf imagery. The broadcast then transitions back to Nationwide Tour coverage, showing Jimmy Walker’s missed birdie at 18 and Paul Gow’s bunker shot and resulting birdie putt at the 9th. Early leaderboard graphics identify the event as the Pete Dye West Virginia Classic, with D.A. Points leading after a 65. The visuals and audio confirm this is a televised Nationwide Tour event at Pete Dye Golf Club, not raw club-shot footage.

title: Feature on the Abandoned Mine Tunnel Behind the 6th Green
summary: A narrated feature describes how coal mining underlies the Pete Dye Golf Club property and shows the abandoned mine tunnel behind the 6th green. The camera moves through the timbered entrance and down the cool, dim corridor, with a sign reading “ABANDONED AREA #2 NORTH – DO NOT PROCEED.” The narration notes that the tunnel is about a dozen degrees cooler and is a unique way to walk from the 6th to the 7th.

title: Front-Nine Action & Course/Mine Feature
chapter: Front-Nine Action & Course/Mine Feature
summary: Coverage cycles through multiple players on the front nine: Ryuji Imada’s precise iron at the 9th, Mark Wurtz’s strong play at the 12th, Brad Adamonis’ blind second shot at 18 (a Pete Dye design feature where the flag is hidden), and others. A narrated feature segment highlights the coal-mining heritage of West Virginia and the abandoned mine tunnel behind the 6th green at Pete Dye Golf Club, emphasizing the course’s unique integration of mining history. Commercials for Porsche, MAC Burrows drivers, Open Championship Week, PlayGolfAmerica, and various sponsors intersperse the golf action.

title: Nationwide Tour Round 1 Highlights & Leaderboard Context
chapter: Nationwide Tour Round 1 Highlights & Leaderboard Context
summary: The broadcast settles into a rhythm of showing live shots and taped highlights from the first round: D.A. Points’ 65, Nick Watney’s course-record 63, Bryce Molder’s birdie run, and strong play from players like Warren Schutte, Jeff Gove, and others. The commentators praise Pete Dye Golf Club’s design and the LaRosa family’s role in developing a first-class venue. Multiple leaderboard graphics show the depth of the field and the cut line at -1. Golf Central updates and Open Championship promos appear, along with sponsor IDs for Nationwide, West Virginia Tourism, National Mining Association, Cleveland Golf, Srixon, and others. The course’s coal cars and mine remnants are shown as part of the club’s visual identity.

title: Second-Round Coverage: D.A. Points, Molder, Watney in Contention
chapter: Second-Round Coverage: D.A. Points, Molder, Watney in Contention
summary: The telecast moves into live second-round coverage. D.A. Points continues his strong play, making birdies at 2, 3, 5, and 6 to reach -10 and tie Bryce Molder at the top. Highlights show Molder’s birdies at 6, 8, 9, and 12, and Watney’s birdie at 18 and eagle try at 8. The commentators discuss how soft conditions and lack of wind have made Pete Dye Golf Club “ripe for scoring,” noting that Pete Dye himself might be uneasy about the low scores. They also emphasize the course’s strategic demands, such as the blind 18th approach and the multi-contoured 17th green. Numerous other players—Paul Gow, Ryuji Imada, Mark Wurtz, Hunter Haas, Franklin Langham, Scott Gutschewski, Todd Demsey, Jeff Gove, Kevin Johnson, Ty Tryon, Bill Lunde, Charles Warren—are shown hitting approaches and putts, illustrating the course’s variety and difficulty.

title: D.A. Points’ Birdie Run to Tie the Lead
summary: D.A. Points, already coming off a 65, makes back-to-back birdies at 5 and 6, then another at the 6th in the second round to reach -10 and tie Bryce Molder at -11. His putting is described as confident and decisive, with the commentators noting he’s “not missing the center of the hole.”

title: Course Conditions Interview with Superintendent Gary Grandstaff
chapter: Course Conditions Interview with Superintendent Gary Grandstaff
summary: During a lull in live action, Brian Anderson and Kurt Byram introduce Gary Grandstaff, the superintendent of Pete Dye Golf Club. In an on-camera interview by the lake, Grandstaff explains that they changed the sand in 106 bunkers just a month before the event, compacting them to firm up conditions. He notes that rain early in the week softened the greens more than intended, making birdies easier and long putts rare. He credits the PGA Tour staff for helping with course preparation and expresses pride in the course as a “treasure” for West Virginia. The segment underscores the behind-the-scenes effort to present a championship-caliber Pete Dye design and how weather can thwart those intentions.

title: Gary Grandstaff Explains Championship Course Setup
summary: Course superintendent Gary Grandstaff is interviewed lakeside about preparing Pete Dye Golf Club for the Nationwide Tour. He explains that they replaced sand in 106 bunkers and compacted them to firm up conditions, but early-week rain softened the greens more than intended, making birdies easier. He credits the PGA Tour staff for their help and calls the process “a lot of fun,” underscoring pride in the course as a West Virginia treasure.

title: Mid-Round Grind: 10th and 15th Holes, Cut-Line Drama
chapter: Mid-Round Grind: 10th and 15th Holes, Cut-Line Drama
summary: The coverage focuses on some of Pete Dye Golf Club’s toughest holes. The 10th is repeatedly described as the hardest hole on the course, with only eight birdies and many doubles; players like Hunter Haas, Scott Gutschewski, Franklin Langham, and others struggle with its mounded green. The par-5 15th is shown as a reachable but dangerous hole, with players like Darron Stiles, P.H. Horgan III, Charles Warren, Kevin Johnson, and Gavin Coles laying up or going for it in two, often leaving tricky pitches near water and rocks. The 17th’s controversial multi-humped green is diagrammed on-screen, with Kurt Byram’s telestrator showing how balls can roll off if distance control is off. Leaderboard graphics and commentary track the cut line at -1 and how players like Kevin Johnson, Troy Matteson, Todd Demsey, and others are hovering around it.

title: Golf Central Updates & Open Championship Context
chapter: Golf Central Updates & Open Championship Context
summary: Several Golf Central update segments appear, hosted from Orlando and studio sets, providing scores and analysis from the 133rd Open Championship at Royal Troon. Leaderboards show Skip Kendall leading at -7, with Thomas Levet, K.J. Choi, Barry Lane, Vijay Singh, Ernie Els, Colin Montgomerie, Mike Weir, Retief Goosen, Phil Mickelson, Tiger Woods, and others in pursuit. These updates are intercut with Nationwide Tour coverage, reinforcing the Golf Channel’s broader coverage of professional golf. Promos for Open Championship Week, Sprint Post Game, and PGA TOUR.com Tour Pass appear, along with sponsor IDs for Grey Goose, Circuit City, and others. This situates the Pete Dye West Virginia Classic within the larger professional golf calendar.
